If the characters confront Mireene, Arbek comes to her aid after telepathic communication, commanding the characters to leave. Mireene doesn't know about the pirate attack but Arbek does. He never spills the secret, even if threatened with death.

Stashed in Mireene's cottage is Arbek's diary, detailing how he tricked Mayor Soman Galt into divulging the location of Kzixxaro, and a plan for a pirate attack headed by Bartholomew Blackdagger the night after the characters arrive in Neverwinter. There is also correspondence between Arbek and Sea King Tentrix. Characters who can read {@language Thieves' Cant}, or who succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence check, they discover that Tentrix is hidden in Nelanthers.

entries.name: N12. Pirates' Skyhold
entries: North of the city floats an almost inaccessible earthmote named Pirates' Skyhold. Atop this floating hunk of stone is a fortress built by pirates long ago to store their treasures. The fort drew the attention of the {@creature adult black dragon} Garrundar the Vile, who destroyed most of the fortress, killed the resident pirates, and claimed the earthmote for his own. Since then, many have attempted to oust the dragon, but all have failed.

Luckily for Neverwinter, Garrundar is too lazy to do much himself, preferring to hire out his mercenaries to gather treasure. One of the many slain by Garrundar was Bartholomew Blackdagger, a sky pirate captain whose crew attempted to plunder the dragon's hoard. Bartholomew was cursed with undeath by Garrundar and now works as a mercenary for the black dragon.

entries.name: Development
entries: To access Pirates' Skyhold the characters must fly 100 feet to the earthmote. There, they encounter Garrundar the Vile and his lizardfolk minions (ten {@creature lizardfolk} and four {@creature lizardfolk shaman|mm|lizardfolk shamans}). If the characters can defeat or sneak past Garrundar they have the chance to plunder his hoard (11,000 gp, 7,000 sp, 9,000 cp, three {@item coral} stones (100 gp each), three {@item moonstone|dmg|moonstones} (50 gp each), a crown of bronze sculpted to resemble a seaweed wreath (250 gp), and a {@item bag of holding} containing a {@item spell scroll (4th level)|dmg|spell scroll} of {@spell blight}, two {@item potion of greater healing|dmg|potions of greater healing}, and a {@item crossbow bolt case|phb|bolt case} inlaid with mother of pearl (150 gp) filled with twenty {@item +1 crossbow bolt|dmg|+1 bolts}. Perhaps the most precious treasure is the crashed Halruuan airship, Scuttering Skylark, that belonged to Bartholomew Blackdagger.

The Scuttering Skylark desperately needs repairing. This requires the assistance of a spellcaster who knows both the {@spell fly} and {@spell levitate} spells, as well as the use of a forge and smithy to create a control rod of silver, capped with gold. The entire repair costs 20,000 gp. What remains of the ship is not dissimilar to a {@item sailing ship|CallfromtheDeep}, but has an additional sail where the rudder would be, six oar-like sails protruding from the sides, and numerous enormous turtle shells built into the hull.

Learning how to pilot the ship requires downtime spent {@variantrule Downtime Activity: Research|xge|Researching} (see "{@book Downtime Activites|phb|8|Downtime Activities|0}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook} or {@book chapter 2|xge|2|downtime activities} of {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything}) in an arcane library such as Candlekeep. If the research is successful the character becomes proficient in vehicles (air). See chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} for the {@item airship|dmg|ship's statistics}.

The characters could potentially discover the planned attack on Neverwinter by Bartholomew Blackdagger's portion of the Black Armada from Garrundar. If the dragon's life is threatened, or the right price is met (1,000 gp), he provides the information the characters desire.

Blackdagger's ghost ship arrives the night after characters arrive in Neverwinter. They kill Kzixxaro the aboleth in the lower vaults of the House of Knowledge. Garrundar knows the Kraken Society has something to do with it, but doesn't know why they want Kzixxaro dead, only that he'll be paid well for the use of his mercenaries. Garrundar was contacted by someone named Arbek, who he believes is working for Sea King Tentrix.

entries.name: Attack on Neverwinter
entries: The night after the characters arrive, Neverwinter is attacked by a ghost ship crewed by forty skeletons and captained by {@creature Captain Bartholomew Blackdagger|CallfromtheDeep|Bartholomew Blackdagger} (CE male human {@creature revenant}) and his mates a {@creature wight} and a {@creature sword wraith warrior|mtf}. Their aim is to sail up the Neverwinter River to the House of Knowledge, storm the Lower Vaults, and destroy Kzixxaro the {@creature Kzixxaro|CallfromtheDeep|aboleth} who lairs down there.

The ghost ship can only be embarked upon by undead; all other creatures and objects pass through it. The ship is bound to water at all times. Because of this, the ship can sail straight through the three bridges of Neverwinter and right up to the House of Knowledge before the undead crew disembarks.

The pirates are mercenaries hired through Garrundar the Vile. Arbek, a member of the Kraken Society, paid the dragon to send the pirates to attack Kzixxaro, whose location was given away by Mayor Soman Galt.

entries.name: Beginning the Encounter
entries: The attack is launched the night after the characters arrive. Read or paraphrase the following:

It is a foggy night in Neverwinter. A thick sea mist has rolled in from the ocean and into the docks and coastal wards of the city. The usual hustle and bustle of the city seems subdued by the pressing damp. The sea seems lit by an ethereal blue light.

Over time, the strange light seems to solidify into an enormous, spectral galleon which emerges from the mists and cuts through the waves like a hot knife through butter. Standing proud atop the foredeck is a man with flesh as pale as death, dressed in a tricorn hat and wielding a midnightblack blade.

Unless the characters have intervened, the necromantic aura of the ship animates twenty {@creature zombie|mm|zombies} from Neverdeath graveyard (see "{@area N7. Neverdeath|nw7|x}") who shamble through the streets, threatening the citizens of Neverwinter. The characters must decide whether to tackle this threat or chase the ghostly galleon to the House of Knowledge.

Once the pirates reach the temple, they meet little resistance from the startled {@deity Oghma|Faerûnian|scag|Oghmanite} priests and quickly descend to the lower vaults and assault Kzixxaro and his followers. The development of this encounter is detailed in "{@area N6. House of Knowledge|nw6|x}".
Once Kzixxaro is killed the pirates flee Neverwinter the same way they entered. If Blackdagger is killed the ship disappears, leaving remaining crew stranded.

entries.name: Kzixxaro & Followers
entries: The treasure that these creatures have accumulated is detailed in {@area N6. House of Knowledge|nw6|x}.

entries.name: Undead Crew
entries: The crew of the ghostly galleon carry no treasure with them, save their weapons and armour.

entries.name: Bartholomew Blackdagger
entries: Unlike the rest of his crew, Blackdagger has accumulated a few valuable trinkets. He wears a silver chain with a black dragon pendant around his neck (50 gp), a gold ring with a carnelian skull (60 gp), and a black leather belt with a golden buckle (25 gp). Blackdagger also wields a black steel {@item scimitar|phb} with a bejewelled basket hilt (250 gp).

entries.name: Development
entries: The only way to prevent the pirates killing Kzixxaro is to destroy them. The characters may not wish to prevent the death of Kzixxaro, but are likely to want to destroy the crew.

If Kzixxaro survives, it attempts to recruit the characters into the Abolethic Sovereignty. If it cannot do so, it sends agents to hunt them down and prevent them from telling Neverember. If the characters choose to take Kzixxaro's side, the aboleth to helps them assault Ascarle in {@adventure chapter 5|CallfromtheDeep|9}.

If Kzixxaro is killed, the undead crew head back to the ocean, and eventually return to Pirates' Skyhold to serve Garrundar the Vile once again. Garrundar the Vile or the undead crew might end up making another appearance later in the campaign against the characters.

entries.name: Neverwinter Quests
entries: The NPCs the characters meet in Neverwinter should survive the pirate attack, but some may be taken captive at the DM's discretion. Remaining NPCs bestow quests upon the characters, encouraging them to further explore the Sword Coast and Island Kingdoms. This allows them to gather information, experience, and items that help them mount a successful attack on the Kraken Society, and Sea King Tentrix.
Whether the characters travel by sea or over land, use appendix A to stage random encounters along the way.

entries.name: Theryis & Toram's Quest
entries: Members of the Harpers are approached by the halfsiblings. Toram raves about the lack of communication between Harpers, and Theryis tries to calm him. The pair are concerned that they weren't warned about the pirate attack and haven't heard anything from The Berg; a floating, hollow iceberg that the Harpers use as a base in the Sea of Swords. Theyris has tried to contact the base's leader, Thea Wisecobble (NG non-binary lightfoot halfling {@creature bard|vgm}) but has received nothing back. Theryis and Toram introduce the characters to Sandyse Thunderquill (see {@area N10. House of a Thousand Faces|nw10|x}) who protects a Harper {@spell teleportation circle} in an unassuming rowhouse in Neverwinter.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters accept they are teleported to The Berg, which is currently floating between Ruathym and Gundarlun. The base has been overrun by ten Kraken Society {@creature cultist|mm|cultists} led by Svetlana Brokenstag (CN female Illuskan human {@creature transmuter|vgm}) and supported by three {@creature yeti|mm|yetis}. The cultists don't know they're working for Slarkrethel, let alone Zellix'Phor. Svetlana is telepathically linked to the elder brain and can receieve messages from it, though it makes her ears bleed. If Svetlana is about to reveal important information, Zellix'Phor uses an action on its turn to deal 40 psychic damage to her. This damage is enough to kill Svetlana immediately. Svetlana has been mutated by the influence of the Slarkrethel; she has fins on her forearms and calves, skin folds that resemble gills on her neck, and glassy blue-green eyes.

All Harpers aboard are locked in cells as the The Berg moves toward Ascarle. The imprisoned Harper contingent includes Thea Wisecobble (see above), two {@creature noble|mm|nobles}, and four {@creature spy|mm|spies} (although The Berg can house 25 individuals), each with one level of {@condition exhaustion}. They are guarded day and night by the yetis, while the cultists operate The Berg's magical propulsion mechanism and patrol the base.

The Krakenar are unaware that Gumph the {@creature flumph} is aboard thanks to his {@item ring of invisibility}. Gumph has been spying on Svetlana and shares the following information with the characters:

items: The Berg was captured as it could alert the Sword Coast of future pirate attacks.
The Berg is being manoeuvred to the north of Purple Rocks.
Svetlana will be rewarded with untold knowledge should she succeed in this task.

entries: If characters liberate The Berg from the Kraken Society they are each rewarded with a magic item (roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} or allow each player to choose one item from that table). In addition, the characters gain access to the Harper {@spell teleportation circle} network which has permanent circles in Baldur's Gate, Mirabar, Neverwinter and Waterdeep.

entries.name: Mardred the Many's Quest
entries: The characters receive an urgent message from Pettigrin Handel (LG male Chondathan human {@creature apprentice wizard|vgm}) who appears in a torn robe with wounds on his arms. After composing himself, he tells the characters that green aliens have attacked Cloak Tower. They tried to unlock the vault beneath the tower, but failed. Now they are using the apprentices to threaten Mardred. Pettigrin managed to slip away by successfully casting {@spell misty step} for the first time.

entries.name: Development
entries: If characters rush to Cloak Tower, they find everything Pettigrin said is true. The door is battered down and several windows are smashed. Hanging from one of these is the body of a tall, yellow-green humanoid with grey dreadlocks and ornate armour. Characters with a connection to the Astral Plane recognise this creature as a githyanki. Floating above the tower is an astral skiff; a flying vessel that requires three githyanki crew and carries up to twelve passengers. The ship can travel at a 15 miles per hour, and {@spell plane shift} to the Astral Plane.

Inside, the tower is deserted save for the lowest floor. Here, three githyanki warriors and Sarth Tra'ados the githyanki knight hold three apprentice wizards captive, female Shield dwarf illusionist with a robe of stars) relinquishes her robe and the other six inside the vault. The githyanki want the robes to allow their warriors to pursue fleeing mind flayers. Mardred has only 1 hit point remaining, and is close to opening the vault (which is protected by an arcane lock and a glyph of warding: explosive runes) as she cannot bear to see the children hurt.

The characters can attack or bargain with the githyanki. The githyanki know that mind flayers have crashed on Gundarlun, but don't know the connection the elder brain and the Kraken Society. If the characters protect Mardred and the apprentices, each is rewarded with a robe of stars. The githyanki are based in Flame Fault, a githyanki crèche on the island of Tuern. If characters ally with the githyanki, they can be flown to there in the astral skiff.

entries.name: Len-jes' Quest
entries: A member of the Neverwinter Watch working for Len-jes asks the characters to meet with the harbourmaster at the Beached Leviathan the next evening. Len-jes has bought them a fine meal as thanks for their efforts to protect the city. She tells the characters that she is responsible for the safety of Neverwinter's docks which, she explains, requires many mercenary sailors from Mintarn, hired through the White Sails company. Of late, hired ships have been turning up with fewer mercenaries than paid for. She asks the characters to investigate, offering the use of a {@item sailing ship|CallfromtheDeep} called Dawn's Gem, and a reward of 1,000 gp in gemstones.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters travel to Mintarn they are welcomed onto the island. Mintarn is a popular safe-haven for criminals as it has a 'no questions asked' policy, making it a great neutral ground, though populated with dangerous clientele (see "{@adventure Mintarn|CallfromtheDeep|7|Mintarn}" in chapter 3 for more information).

Before the characters make it beyond the docks, they are attacked by {@creature Captain Callous - Chapter Two|CallfromtheDeep|Captain Callous} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and his crew, or by a drunken dragonborn with an eyepatch named {@creature Farihaan Grathyozterix|CallfromtheDeep} (NE female bronze dragonborn {@creature swashbuckler|vgm}) and her five {@creature thug} lackeys. If characters defeat the pirates, they offer information in return for their freedom. They tell the characters that local folk blame the dragon Hoondarrh for the missing crew. They also mention that Tyrant Bloeth Embuirhan (LN female Chondathan human {@creature gladiator} with 90 hit points) might know more.

If characters visit local inns they find the claims to be true. All the locals blame the missing mercenaries on Hoondarrh. A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check reveals they are lying, but any attempts to press the matter are met with hostility that could quickly turn to violence.

If characters travel to Castle Mintarn they are greeted directly by Bloeth, who has heard of their endeavours in Neverwinter. She delights in the characters' tale of the pirate attack, treating them to a meal and a few bottles of Mintarn's famous green wine. If the characters mention the missing mercenaries, she asks them to follow her. She takes them up a tower of Castle Mintarn. From here, the characters can see that two of the towers have been destroyed, which Bloeth explains as the work of Hoondarrh the Red Rage after the island failed to provide tribute one year. She then points to Skaduarak, the dragon's mountain lair which rises up from the sea to the north. Bloeth blames Hoondarrh for the ship attacks, but hints that a contribution to the tribute might reveal more information. If the characters give Bloeth 250 gp or more, she tells them to explore Narino, a sunken city to the south.

Narino is detailed in full in {@adventure chapter 3|CallfromtheDeep|7|Narino}. It is an abandoned merfolk city occupied by Mei Ling (LE female {@creature vampire} with a swim speed of 30 ft.). Mei Ling is responsible for the disappearances. She used to feed exclusively on merfolk, but the recent abundance of ships has given her a taste for human blood. Characters might convince Mei Ling to stick to a merfolk diet, bribe her to avoid White Sails ships, or attempt to kill her. If successful, Len-jes rewards them when they return to Neverwinter. If the characters fail, Len-jes still provides a reward of 250 gp for any information.

entries.name: Dagult Neverember's Quest
entries: Lord Protector Dagult Neverember arranges a meeting with the characters. He thanks them for their assistance defending the city and rewards them with 100 gp each plus the privilege of staying at the High Hall any time they desire. Dagult also gives them command of a Tarnian mercenary sailing ship called Dragon's Ire should they desire.

After rewarding them, Lord Protector Neverember asks the characters visit Luskan on his behalf. He believes the City of Sails must know more about the increased piracy. Dagult gives the characters a Lord's Alliance emblem which they can present to the High Captains to gain an audience.

entries.name: Development
entries: After travelling to Luskan, the characters can arrange a meeting with the five High Captains provided they show the Lord's Alliance emblem. Ship Suljack, under the command of Captain Dagmaer, is responsible for the control of piracy and claims to have no part in the attack on Neverwinter. If the characters mention Bartholomew Blackdagger Captain Throa of Ship Taerl pipes up, claiming that Blackdagger has assaulted her own vessels in the past. Throa knows that Blackdagger is a mercenary under the command of Garrundar the Vile, a black dragon who lairs on an earthmote near Neverwinter. Garrundar is a greedy oaf and would no doubt accept a bribe to reveal his client.

If the characters pursue this lead, they can question Garrundar ({@area N12. Pirate's Skyhold|nw12|x}), which leads them to Arbek on Fisher's Float ({@area N11. Fisher's Float|nw11|x}) and then to the Nelanther (see {@adventure chapter 3|CallfromtheDeep|7} for more information). Dagult happily arranges to pay the 1,000 gp bribe for Garrundar.

entries.name: Kzixxaro's Quest
entries: If the characters ally themselves with the Abolethic Sovereignty, Kzixxaro contacts them telepathically. It has been telepathically probing the local area and has discovered an individual on Fisher's Float that is acting as a telepathic conduit. Kzixxaro wants the characters to find this individual and discover who they work for, as they could pose a threat to the Abolethic Sovereignty's plans.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters make it there, play through the events detailed in "{@area N11. Fisher's Float|nw11|x}". The characters end up confronting Arbek, a Krakenar who orchestrated the attack on Baldur's Gate. If the characters search his belongings, they discover communication between him and Sea King Tentrix, who seems to be somewhere in the Nelanther Isles.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: Characters gain levels in this chapter by completing the goals summarised below:

items: Characters who defend one of the Sword Coast cities advance to 6th level.
For each additional city defended, the characters may gain an additional level.
Characters who undertake additional quests have the chance to gain character levels at your discretion, advance one level per two quests as a rough guide.

entries.name: Waterdeep
entries: Waterdeep, the City of Splendours, is perhaps the most important city on the Sword Coast. This great metropolis stands as example of what a great city might be in wealth, influence, and stability. The city is ruled by Open Lord, Lady Laeral Silverhand, who supplanted Dagult Neverember. She is supported by the Masked Lords, who make policies for the city. Unlike other Sword Coast cities, Waterdeep has managed to remain mostly out of trouble in recent years.

Waterdeep's law and order is maintained by the City Watch, whose stern policing has kept the city relatively safe from criminals. Trade in the city is overseen by guilds who monitor the pricing and quality of each artisan to ensure accordance with their high standards. The city's military, the City Guard, staff garrisons, patrol roads and watch posts, and serve as body- and gate-guards.

Waterdeep is split into wards. The Dock Ward, which contains Deepwater Harbour, is mostly warehouses and yards which facilitate sea trade. The South Ward is a mercantile district, where caravan masters and merchants sell their wares, though it is poorer than the Trade Ward where most of the money changes hands. The Castle Ward encompasses government buildings and Blackstaff Tower. The City of the Dead is a park and cemetery. The North Ward is home to the nobility of Waterdeep, though isn't as wealthy as the Sea Ward, which houses many temples, the richest of the nobility, and retired adventurers.

entries.name: Waterdeep Locations
entries: The following locations are identified on the Waterdeep map.

entries.name: W1. Deepwater Harbour
entries: Waterdeep's dock is a bustling melee of ships, sailors, and criminals. During the day it is easy to get lost in the throng of people, but at night the lack of streetlights makes it a haven for rogues and wrongdoers. The Defender of the Harbour is a seasoned veteran named Reynard Blackbrook (LG male Chondathan human {@creature veteran}), who commands ten {@creature guard|mm|guards} and three {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of the City Guard. Blackbrook was an adventurer, but retired after losing an arm fighting the Stormwind pirate fleet. The missing arm has been replaced with a shield bearing the Waterdeep arms.
Beneath the water is a sprawling settlement of merfolk and sea elves called Tharqualnaar. The folk of this town work for the City Guard and trade with sailors and merchants who visit the harbour.

entries.name: Development
entries: The characters can convince the underwater denizens of Deepwater Harbour to let them visit Tharqualnaar with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, or a donation of 200 gp to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag}. The characters are escorted by four merfolk {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} through a marine garden filled with coral and anemones to a palace carved from the rocky seafloor.

Inside, the characters meet Chieftess Antinua Reefsilver (LG female merfolk {@creature noble}) and Uth'ivellios Cithrea (CG male sea elf {@creature priest} of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf}) and his pet {@creature dolphin|vgm}. The audience chamber in which they meet is enchanted with a permanent {@spell water breathing} spell. The leaders of Tharqualnaar are becoming suspicious that there is a malenti in their ranks; a sahuagin born with a mutation making them resemble an aquatic elf. Paranoia is spreading through Tharqualnaar that an attack is imminent.

The paranoia is not misplaced. There is a {@creature malenti|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) named Ilanquor within the underwater city. Ilanquor managed to store the stolen {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) within {@area Umberlee's Cache|wd3|x} (in {@area u4|uc4}) so that the sahuagin raiders could find it when they attack.

entries.name: W2. Outer Gates
entries: The outer wall of Waterdeep has three gates that permit entry day and night. The North Gate is manned by four {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} and two {@creature guard|mm|guards} of the City Guard and permits entry to the richer areas of the city so long as papers of identification are provided. The East and South Gate are manned by two {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} and four {@creature guard|mm|guards} of the City Guard and permit entry without identification to the poorer wards.

entries.name: W3. Umberlee's Cache
entries: Umberlee's Cache is an underwater cave in the Deepwater Harbour that is filled with tithes given to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} by sailors and the general populace during the festival of Fleetswake. The entrance to the dungeon is marked by the Deepwater Beacon, a pillar of light that shoots up through the water. It is guarded by four merfolk {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} and one merfolk {@creature priest}, as well as their five {@creature giant sea horse|mm|giant sea horses}.

entries.name: Development
entries: When the sahuagin raid begins one of the {@creature sahuagin baron|mm|sahuagin barons}, two {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep|sahuagin raiders} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), five {@creature sahuagin}, and four {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks} split off from the main force. They kill all but one of the merfolk guards and head to {@area u4|uc4} for the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep}. The final merfolk escapes and alerts the City Guard, who ask the characters for help. If the characters search for Umberlee's Cache, read or paraphrase the following:

On the ocean floor not far from the Deepwater Beacon is an isolated cavern entrance with coral growing all around. A few stray coins lie scattered about the entrance, though they are slowly being dragged inward by a strong current.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Umberlees Cache (Player).png}.}

entries.name: U1. The Descent
entries: The characters cannot see unless they have {@sense darkvision} or a light source. Unless they resist, they are dragged to the hole at the bottom of area U1 in five turns.

A narrow tunnel leads down to an enormous sunken chamber with fist-sized crystals covering the walls. The centre of the chamber spirals down like a vortex to a rocky bottom punctured with a gaping hole. A strong current pulls the seawater past you toward the fissure. Spectral forms circle around in the currents.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Circling in the water are three sea wraiths ({@creature specter|mm|spectres} with a 60 ft. swim speed but no fly speed); the trapped souls of drowned sailors who failed to pay tribute to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag}, and now guard her hoard. They attack creatures not wearing a {@item holy symbol|phb} of Umberlee.
Creatures that enter without uttering a prayer to Umberlee summon a {@creature bearded devil} from {@area u5|uc5} that arrives in four turns and attacks.

entries.name: Current
entries: The hole in the floor of the chamber sucks seawater down into {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag|Umberlee's} domain. Any Medium or smaller creature or unsecured object is pulled 5 feet toward the hole at the start of their turn unless they succeed on a DC 10 Strength saving throw. An object pulled into the hole disappears to the Outer Planes. A creature pulled into the hole takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage and is shot up 50 feet back into the chamber.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check while {@action search|phb|searching} the cavern floor finds a total of 18 gp, 14 sp, and 13 cp, a {@item potion of water breathing}, and a {@item +1 scimitar} with a pearl pommel.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the sahuagin have arrived there are two dead sahuagin floating in the water, and three {@creature sahuagin} and a {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) fighting the two reamining sea wraiths. In two rounds, the {@creature bearded devil} emerges from {@area u5|uc5} and attacks the sahuagin (see {@area u5|uc5} for more information).

Dimly lit by glowing purple anemones, this small shrine contains an altar upon which offerings have been placed and two stone kraken statues covered in thin, sheet-like seaweed and barnacles. Crossed tridents hang over the altar.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Atop the shrine are three ceramic vases with wave motifs (50 gp each) and a platinum ring engraved with a symbol of {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} (100 gp). Two {@item trident|phb|tridents} hang above the altar (5 gp each). A character who steals from the shrine is cursed by Umberlee. They immediately run out of breath and can't speak for 1 minute.

entries.name: Offerings
entries: Characters who place an offering of 50 gp or more on the altar and pray to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} gain a swim speed of 30 feet and the ability to breathe water for 1 hour.

A natural cavern sprouts off from the descending spiral stairs. The cavern is cloaked in shadow and the water within is murky and warm. A mass of writhing tentacles inside the cavern probes and explores the surroundings.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature tribute gatherer|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) lair in the cave. If characters wait long enough, the creatures leave the cavern to scour {@area u1|uc1} for misplaced treasures, which they drag into the hole. This includes the items mentioned in {@area area u1's|uc1|x} treasure subheading.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the sahuagin have arrived there are two dead reef sharks and one dead tribute gatherer. The reamining two {@creature tribute gatherer|CallfromtheDeep|tribute gatherers} are locked in combat with a {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and two {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks}.
The chamber ahead is unnaturally dark. The walls are coated with a film of oil or ink which hungrily devours any light. Sitting dead centre in the chamber is a large, black iron treasure chest.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The unnatural darkness comes from a {@creature reekmurk|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) which is stretched across the walls and ceiling of a chamber.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest has two keys. Dread High Trident Abeline Nerovarco has one, the malenti Ilanquor has the other. The chest can be smashed open with a successful DC 25 Strength check, or unlocked with a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Inside is the stolen {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) nestled on a bed of seaweed which is dotted with pearls (1,000 gp for all the pearls).

entries.name: Development
entries: If the sahuagin have arrived there is a {@creature sahuagin baron} trying to retrieve the chest. Both have half their hit points remaining. The baron retrieves the chest on the following turn and flees unless the characters intervene.

A short stone corridor leads to a beautifully decorated hall. Eight pillars sculpted with coral-like forms rise to a vaulted ceiling decorated with shell motifs. Bas-reliefs one the walls depict nautical scenes including a galleon being sunk by a kraken, and a wreck being smashed by a tempestuous storm.
The floor is tiled with tiny pieces of ceramic and forms a mosaic of twin crashing waves.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Although initially empty, a creature enters {@area u1|uc1} without uttering a prayer to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} summons a {@creature bearded devil} with a 30 ft. swim speed and a beard of eels is summoned in this room. The devil appears in four rounds and immediately seeks out intruders.

If the characters leave immediately, the bearded devil ceases to attack them. If the characters explain there is treasure being hidden there and succeed on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, the devil helps them search. When they discover the chest in {@area u4|uc4}, the devil wants to throw it into the hole in {@area u1|uc1}. Convincing it to not requires a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. Otherwise, the characters must take the chest by force.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The eastern wall's bas-relief depicts the storm scene described above. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice a thin seam of bubbles around the edge of a whirlpool. A successful DC 19 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals this to be a secret door that can be opened by twisted the stone slightly. The door leads to {@area u6|uc6}.

The section of wall swings open, revealing a corridor lit by magical blue flames on either side. At the end of the corridor is a small shrine housing a huge altar of bone. Atop this are half a dozen black candles which flicker with the same blue fire. Sticking out from the shrine are several scroll cases.

entries.name: Light
entries: This room is lit by blue {@spell continual flame} spells, both in the corridor and on the candles.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Jutting from between the bones of the altar are three whalebone {@item map or scroll case|phb|scroll cases} (150 gp each). Each contains a {@item spell scroll}: {@spell alter self}, {@spell bane}, and {@spell summon lesser demons|xge}.

entries.name: Trap
entries: If anything is taken from the altar by a non-{@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag|Umberlant}, roll initiative. On initiative count 20 the door to the chamber slams shut. On initiative count 10 the water heats up, dealing {@damage 1d6} fire damage to any creature inside; this fire damage overcomes resistances granted by being submerged. On each subsequent initiative count 10, the damage increases increases by {@damage 1d6} to a maximum of {@damage 5d6}.

items.name: Countermeasures.
items.entry: Replacing stolen items stops the trap and opens the door. The trap can also be stopped by opening the door, which requires a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, followed by a successful DC 18 Strength check. Alternatively, any character who stole an item can attempt a DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Religion}) check to beg for mercy. If all characters with stolen items succeed on this check the trap stops and the door opens.

entries.name: Development
entries: The characters should be able to fight off the sahuagin pirates and take the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} from them. If characters return the conch to the Zulpair family Pasha Arain insists they take the conch as payment for investigating the crime.

The conch contains a {@creature marid} named Sultan Klaptikos of the Great Waves. He hails from an underwater coral palace called Underwave west of the Moonshaes. Klaptikos has great knowledge of the underwater locations of Faerûn. He also knows a way to the Elemental Plane of Water and the Citadel of Ten Thousand Pearls.

Characters may use the Sultan in combat and for flawless navigation. If characters treat the Sultan as a friend or patron, rather than slave, Klaptikos might be tempted to stick with the characters even after he has fulfilled the demands placed upon him by his imprisonment.

entries.name: W4. Queenspire
entries: Spiralling up from the sandbar to the southeast of Waterdeep is a shell-like tower with a glistening, pale-pink exterior and live corals growing around its base. This church of {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} is presided over by Dread High Trident Abeline Nerovarco (LE female Tethyrian human {@creature kraken priest|vgm} wielding a {@item trident of fish command}) who, like many before her, pays dual homage to Umberlee and her chosen aspect Slarkrethel. Unlike most of the Kraken Society, Abeline knows the cult is headed by the kraken. The Dread High Trident keeps her allegiance to Slarkrethel a secret, sending her underlings out to fulfil the kraken's requests.

It is through this method that Dread High Trident Abeline came into possession of a {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep}. The kraken commanded her to recover the magic item and bequeath it to Umberlee, which she did without question. Abeline does not know that the request actually came from Zellix'Phor, who wants to bind the genie into service.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters investigate the stolen {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep}, they may eventually track it back to the church of {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag}. If the characters start poking around the Queenspire or asking too many questions, Dread High Trident Abeline becomes more and more hostile and might end up trying to forcefully remove the characters from the tower. Two {@creature priest|mm|priests} and five {@creature acolyte|mm|acolytes} assist her.

If the characters show Abeline an item that connects the sahuagin with something alien, such as the {@item shield of far sight|vgm} from the Wreck of the Golden Crown, Abeline becomes confused and angry. The item indicates that there is something amiss with Slarkrethel, as she believed that the kraken had sent the sahuagin to her. See "{@area Dread High Trident Abeline Nerovarco's Quest|wdqanq|x}".

entries.name: W5. Tymora's Blessing
entries: Named after the Lady Luck, this seedy tavern-come-casino promises a shot at meagre winnings and an unforgettable evening with unusual clientele. Tymora's Blessing is owned by 'Lady' Gurnin Copperguts (N female shield dwarf {@creature priest} of {@deity Tymora|Faerûnian|SCAG}), an old dwarven woman who takes no nonsense and isn't afraid to punch her way through a problem. She has the ability to {@spell teleport} items to a secret room in the tavern should she wish. This ability is a gift from Tymora.

The tavern has a strict no magic policy, which extends to magic items and applies to everyone save Copperguts herself. Casting spells or using magic items triggers an audible {@spell alarm} spell. This rule is enforced by Grunter, the tavern's {@creature hill giant} doorman. The tavern has securely warded lockers in which visitors can store their magical belongings. Any item seen within the establishment is 'disintegrated'. In truth, they are teleported away by Gurnin to her personal vault, so she can sell them later to a Zhentarim fence.

Although there is no food on offer, the Blessing has several rooms on the third floor (the second floor is little more than an open balcony to provide headspace for Grunter), ranging from Poor to Modest which the characters can hire. The tavern offers a variety of gambling including three dragon ante, lizard racing, and dice. Tymora's is always filled with an unusual range of patrons including drow, dragonborn, hobgoblins, orcs, and tieflings. Many a tall-tale is spun here, and challenges to their veracity normally end in blows.

On the balcony floor is a secret door, which can be detected with a successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check and opened with a DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Inside are {@dice 1d4} magic items of your choice that 'Lady' Copperguts has 'disintegrated'.

entries.name: Development
entries: Zhentarim characters can pick out a table of three {@creature thug|mm|thugs} and three {@creature spy|mm|spies} from the Black Network. Other characters must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. This is a favoured haunt of the Zhents, who have a decent deal with Copperguts.

If the characters ask around about a stolen conch or Haseid Zulpair and succeed on a DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check (with advantage if they are a Zhentarim faction agent) {@creature Rashebyeh Qahtan|CallfromtheDeep} (LE female Bedine human {@creature spy}) reveals that she was tasked with retrieving the item from the Zulpair Villa. Rather than infiltrating the villa, she seduced Hasied and got him to bring the magic item out to boast about it. She proceeded to get him drunk and bring him here, where the item was confiscated and handed over to the Black Network. She doesn't reveal where the conch ended up unless characters bribe her with 500 gp, or threaten her life. The conch's final destination was the Queenspire.

entries.name: W6. Warrens
entries: The Warrens are a network of tunnels adjacent to Waterdeep's sewers that stretch underneath the Dock and Castle Wards of the city. They are inhabited almost exclusively by gnomes and halflings, with the former being the primary occupants. Any gnome or halfling character from Waterdeep knows of the Warrens' existence.

Characters who explore the Dock or Castle Ward and have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice markings on the streets; a wavy dagger in a circle. Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check (advantage for gnomes) realise it is Baravar Cloakshadow's symbol. A successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals each emblem is adjacent to a magically concealed doorway, which can be opened with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check.

The interior of the Warrens is clean and well-lit. Gnomes and halflings go about their lives down here, shooting curious glances to other races who venture in. The tunnels are typically 5 feet in diameter, making travel tough for Medium creatures, and impossible for Large creatures. The characters might meet merchants and craftspeople in the tunnels, or seek out the leader of the community; an extraordinarily ancient gnome called Ompahr Daergech (NG male rock gnome {@creature illusionist|vgm}).

entries.name: Development
entries: Characters who meet with Ompahr and tell him about the pirate attack gain his allegiance in the Waterdeep's defence. Ompahr and the clergy of The Sly One are powerful illusionists and can help the characters by providing distractions for the attacking sahuagin, such as an {@spell illusory dragon|xge}. Characters can also use the Warrens to navigate the city faster than usual, as they offer a direct route between the north and south of Waterdeep.

entries.name: W7. The Yawning Portal
entries: The Yawning Portal is the best-known tavern in Waterdeep if not the entire realms. Although it plays no great part in this adventure, it would be remiss to leave it off the notable locations in Waterdeep. If characters enter the Yawning Portal, refer to {@adventure Waterdeep: Dragon Heist|wdh|1|The Yawning Portal} and {@adventure Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage|wdmm|0|The Yawning Portal} which contain descriptions of the tavern and the mega-dungeon which lies beneath it.

entries.name: W8. Castle Waterdeep
entries: Castle Waterdeep is the enormous residence of Open Lord Lady {@creature Laeral Silverhand|wdh} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and a meeting place for the Council of Masked Lords who rule over the city. The castle is an imposing structure with nine looming towers of huge of grey stone blocks. The only route to the castle is up a steep and winding road peppered with guard towers.

If the characters approach Lady Silverhand with information regarding the pirate attack, she organises a meeting of the Masked Lords to try and combat the situation. With only a handful of ships to spare, the majority of the defence must occur in the Dock Ward alongside the merfolk and sea elves of Tharqualnaar. If the characters are in need of direction, she suggests they head to the {@area Zulpair Villa|wd13|x} in the Sea Ward. Pasha Arain came to her a few days ago about a stolen conch shell of value. Laeral is concerned that the theft might be linked to the impending attack.

entries.name: W9. Inn of the Dripping Dagger
entries: The Dripping Dagger would be an unremarkable inn if it were not for its door. For some unknown reason, the solid old oak portal has a portentous quality. When folk walk through its frame, an echoing voice can be heard proclaiming cryptic prophecies. Whether there is any merit to the omens is contested, but nevertheless the door is enough to bring folk in for a drink or two and to keep the establishment on its feet. The tavern's owner, Westfray Lothuntle (NG female Illuskan human {@creature berserker}) was once an adventurer for hire, but eventually earned enough money to buy shares in the tavern and took it over when its previous owner died. Characters can acquire Modest to Comfortable rooms and meals at the inn. Adventurers receive a 10 percent discount on food here.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters enter the tavern, the door speaks the prophecy:

The shark that walks will rise from the deep,
One moon, one sun, the city will weep.

This is a reference to the sahuagin attack that takes place the night after the characters arrive in Waterdeep. A character can discern the meaning behind the omen with a successful DC 15 Intelligence check.
If the characters are working toward any other quests, you can use the door to give them hints toward their goal, or to push them toward a certain resolution.

entries.name: W10. Blackstaff Tower
entries: Rising above the skyline of the Castle Ward is Blackstaff Tower, home to {@creature Vajra Safahr|wdh} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) the current Blackstaff and leader of Force Grey; a group of elite adventurers tasked with protecting Waterdeep from threats greater than the City Guard and City Watch could handle. Blackstaff Tower is foreboding, made of solid black stone with no windows or doors. Only the Blackstaff and her apprentices can access the tower freely.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters visit the Blackstaff with information about the pirate attack, Vajra is extremely concerned. She knows that only an extremely foolhardy crew would attack the Deepharbour, even with most of the City Navy out of port. The Blackstaff asks the characters to pay a visit to Zelifarn, a {@creature young bronze dragon} who lives in {@area Deepwater Harbour|wd1|x}. Vajra gives each of the characters a {@item potion of water breathing} to complete the mission.

If the characters search for Zelifarn, they find him before long trying to trick some sailors out of their gold. The pesky dragon does the same to the characters if they come to talk with him, although he doesn't put up much resistance if the characters refuse to give him anything. Zelifarn reveals that he saw some robed figures drop a large, black iron treasure chest into the south harbour near the Deepwater Beacon. It seemed like they came from the east. Zelifarn guesses correctly that the merfolk will have collected the chest as a tribute to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} and allowed it to be sucked into {@area Umberlee's Cache|wd3|x}. Zelifarn doesn't know that the chest contains a {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep}, or that the figures were priests of Umberlee working for Dread High Trident Abeline.

entries.name: Force Grey
entries: To be in with a shot of joining Force Grey, a character must first enlist as a Gray Hand with Vajra Safahr. A character who has served in the City Watch or City Guard is eligible to join, as are characters who are willing to swear oaths to defend Waterdeep, its citizens, and its laws with their lives. By doing quests for the Blackstaff and Open Lord, Gray Hands can work their way up the ranks to become a fully-fledged member of Force Grey.

If a character becomes a member of the elite squad, they are supported by Vajra Safahr and other members of the society. This support can come in the form of bail for crimes, the temporary use of an uncommon or rare magic item, or an additional hand in combat from a member.

entries.name: W11. The House of the Moon
entries: The House of the Moon is perhaps the largest temple in Waterdeep, dedicated to the goddess of the moon and navigation, {@deity Selûne|Faerûnian|scag}. The huge, domed temple is surrounded by gilded towers and sports an ornate gate depicting the goddess throwing down her rival, {@deity Shar|Faerûnian|scag}. The creamy grey stone of which the temple is built seems to sparkle, even more so in the moonlight than the sun. The temple is often a bustling hive of activity, with pale-blue robed priests scurrying to and fro.

The temple is presided over by the Priestess of High Moonlight, Melessa Suaril (LG female protector aasimar {@creature priest}). She is hugely proud of her faith and heritage but humbly declares that all her best aspects are gifts from The Moonmaiden.

While characters might choose to visit the House of the Moon for religious reasons, they might also visit because of its link to lycanthropy. Selûnites see lycanthropy as a gift to be embraced, and any lycanthropes within the walls of the temple are capable of controlling their bestial urges. Good-aligned lycanthropes or others devoting their life to Selûne might end up as members of the Silverstar; an elite force of warrior priests who are devoted advocates of freedom and tolerance. Alternatively, characters could be cured of lycanthropy in the temple.

entries.name: W12. High Flagon Gambling House
entries: The High Flagon is a unique, hodgepodge building that is somewhat too large for the street it is on. As well as the sprawling casino itself, there are attached stables, coachhouses, and outbuildings. Numerous wings, gables, turrets, and verandas jut out from the main building, all of which are patrolled night and day by groups of six {@creature guard|mm|guards}. The structure is covered in rain barrels of all shapes and sizes; a safety mechanism against fire in the wooden building.

The interior of the building can be accessed via a grand pair of polished copper doors, also protected by guards. The main chambers within are on the verge of luxury. All the furniture is painted black and consists mostly of highbacked chairs around large oval tables. Toward the rear of the building a busy kitchen constantly pumps out their famous sweet and savoury tarts. The drinks menu is deep, containing all variety of alcoholic beverage including Zzar, a fortified sherry wine popular in Waterdeep but disdained by elves. Rooms and meals of Modest to Wealthy quality can be purchased here. The High Flagon is run by the Harbright family, specifically the cousins Lara and Saleeri (LN female Chondathan human {@creature noble|mm|nobles}), a pair of older women with streaks of grey hair at their temples.

Characters who visit the High Flagon can play all variety of card games with others or against the house. The use of magic is forbidden and could result in permanent expulsion. Brawling, taunting, and cheating of any kind results in being thrown out of the establishment by the many guards.

entries.name: W13. Zulpair Villa
entries: In the centre of the Sea Ward is a lavish villa owned by the Zulpairs; a rich Calishite family consisting of Pasha Arain (LN male Calishite human {@creature noble}) and his son Haseid Zulpair (N male Calishite human {@creature noble}). The family made their fortune trading gemstones in Calimport, eventually becoming one of the most notable merchant families in the city. Unfortunately, brought up poorly, Haseid became unruly and disrespectful, almost resulting in their exile from Calimshan. Exercising foresight, Pasha Arain decided to leave the city with his son and search out new fortunes overseas. The family ended up settling in Waterdeep.

Until recently the Zulpair family had a {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) in their possession. Those that know of its magic think that the power afforded over the genie by the item helped them rise to mercantile power in Calimport.

Within the last tenday, the Zulpairs lost the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep}. The gullible Haseid was seduced by Rashebyeh Qahtan, a Zhentarim faction agent. She tricked him into bringing the conch out on a date to show her. After their meal, they headed to {@area Tymora's Blessing|wd5|x}, a tavern and gambling den which confiscates magic items and sells them to a Zhentarim fence.

entries.name: Development
entries: There are no signs of forced entry or magical intrusion. Characters who succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check while interviewing Haseid determine that he's hiding something. Characters who succeed on a DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) or DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check get Haseid to reveal the truth; that he was showing the item off to a woman he was dating, and it was confiscated by the owner of Tymora's Blessing. Haseid refuses to accept responsibility, blaming everyone else for the theft. Haseid reveals that he can't remember the name of the girl he was seeing, but definitely remembers her laughing when the item was taken from him in the Blessing.

If the characters return with the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} and tell Pasha Arain about the process of its theft, he insists that the characters take it. He doesn't want an item that the Zhentarim, Kraken Society, and Umberlants are after lying around in his house.

entries.name: Attack on Waterdeep
entries: The night after the characters arrive a swarm of sahuagin headed by a {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} with a kraken figurehead spill into the {@area Deepwater Harbour|wd1|x}. The force consists of two {@creature sahuagin baron|mm|sahuagin barons}, five {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep|sahuagin raiders} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and thirty-four {@creature sahuagin}. They are accompanied in the water by ten {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks}. Most of the force plunges into the Dock Ward to take captives while a smaller detachment heads to {@area Umberlee's Cache|wd3|x} to gather the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} which they are expecting to be there. After the initial raid, a {@creature malenti|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) from Tharqualnaar meets them aboard the longship and they take off for the Nelanther Isles.

entries.name: Beginning the Encounter
entries: The attack is launched the night after the characters arrive. Read or paraphrase the following:

As the sun dips beneath the horizon, the city of Waterdeep is assaulted by the blasting of horns. A cacophonous, raucous chorus echoes throughout the docks. Suddenly, jumping up from beneath the still waters of Deepwater Harbour come dozens of sahuagin. Bloodcurdling screams of fear erupt throughout the docks as the sea devils attack.

Characters might want to help defend the harbour which they are able to do by taking on small groups of sahuagin, each led by a raider. The City Guard have their hands full trying to prevent captives being taken and can be of little assistance to the characters. The sahuagin grab Waterdhavians and shove carapace-like armour over them. These are {@item survival mantle|vgm|survival mantles} which allow the captives to breathe underwater.
Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher notice a detachment of sahuagin led by a baron headed toward the Deepwater Beacon.

entries.name: Sahuagin Crew
entries: Each baron carries {@dice 3d6 + 10} gp worth of gems, coins, and trinkets. Each sahuagin carries {@dice 1d4 + 10} gp of the same. The {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} contains a {@item shield of far sight|vgm} and an unlocked chest containing 150 gp, two {@item potion of healing|dmg|potions of healing}, and a {@item potion of invisibility}.

entries.name: Umberlee's Cache
entries: The treasure of the shrine can be found in "{@area W3. Umberlee's Cache|wd3|x}".

entries.name: Development
entries: The aim of the sahuagin is to gather captives and retrieve the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} hidden in {@area Umberlee's Cache|wd3|x}. If they are successful, they meet with the malenti Ilanquor who gives them a key to the chest which contains the conch. Ilanquor then quaffs the {@item potion of invisibility} aboard the {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} and swims back to Tharqualnaar. The marid conch is taken to the Nelanther Isles to Sea King Tentrix, who transports it to Ascarle for Zellix'Phor. When the characters attack Ascarle, the marid is helping to guard the sunken citadel.

If the characters prevent this they get to keep the conch thanks to the cowardice of Pasha Arain (see "{@area W13. Zulpair Villa|wd13|x}"). If the characters release the marid he introduces himself as Sultan Klaptikos of the Great Waves and thanks them for releasing him. He asks the characters if they would mind doing him another favour (see "{@area Sultan Klaptikos of the Great Waves' Quest|wdqskq|x}" in Waterdeep Quests).

entries.name: Waterdeep Quests
entries: The NPCs the characters meet in Waterdeep should survive the sahuagin attack, but some may be taken captive at the DM's discretion. Remaining NPCs bestow quests upon the characters, encouraging them to further explore the Sword Coast and Island Kingdoms. This allows them to gather information, experience, and items that help them mount a successful attack on the Kraken Society, and Sea King Tentrix.
Whether the characters travel by sea or over land, use {@adventure appendix A|CallfromtheDeep|11} to stage random encounters along the way.

entries.name: Laeral Silverhand's Quest
entries: Open Lord Lady Laeral Silverhand arranges a meeting with the characters. She thanks them for their assistance defending the city and rewards them with 100 gp each plus the privilege of staying at Castle Waterdeep any time they desire. Laeral also allows them to take control of a Waterdhavian Navy ship called Ocean's Splendour.

After rewarding them, Laeral asks the characters to visit Luskan. She believes the City of Sails must know more about the increased piracy. Laeral gives the characters a Lord's Alliance emblem, which they can present to the High Captains to gain an audience.

entries.name: Development
entries: After travelling to Luskan the characters can arrange a meeting with the five High Captains provided they show the Lord's Alliance emblem. Ship Suljack, under the command of Captain Dagmaer, is responsible for the control of piracy and claims to have no part in the attack on Waterdeep, spitting at the thought they'd associate with sea devils in such a lowly way. Luskan too has noticed increased piracy in the Sea of Swords that they are not a part of. They fear that the sahuagin and petty pirates are being manipulated by some greater force. Ship Suljack suggests that the characters head to the Nelanther Isles, a stronghold of piracy in the south. Here, they might be able to discover who, or what, is leading the attacks.

entries.name: Abeline Nerovarco's Quest
entries: After the sahuagin attempt to retrieve the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep} from {@area Umberlee's Cache|wd3|x}, Dread High Trident Abeline Nerovarco realises something must be manipulating her telepathic communications with Slarkrethel. The kraken has never associated with sea devils in the past, and Abeline doesn't understand why he would send a whole fleet to Waterdeep when she could have taken the conch to him herself. Abeline tries not to reveal the identity of the Kraken Society's leader but divulges the information if the characters won't help her otherwise.

Abeline asks the characters to escort her to the Cloakwood, just south of Baldur's Gate. She knows of a cavern hideout where the wood meets the cliffs where important members of the Kraken Society meet. If she can attend a meeting with other members, she might be able to understand what's going on. She also asks if the characters wish to join the society. She cannot permit her secret to be spread throughout Waterdeep, and the cult promises great power and knowledge to its members. Characters who join are given a {@item breastplate|phb} embossed with a kraken design.

entries.name: Development
entries: If characters head through the Cloakwood, they are attacked by an evil {@creature treant} which storms through the forest toward them. Realising Abeline is the weakest of the group, it attacks her first. If the characters don't protect Abeline, the treant knocks her {@condition unconscious} with two slam attacks on its first turn in combat.
If the characters head to the Cloakwood via sea, they are attacked by a {@creature hydra} which lairs in the coastal shallows. A similar situation presents itself where Abeline is put at risk.

If the characters protect Abeline she thanks them wholeheartedly and continues to the Kraken Society meeting spot, which she calls Breakhand Cove. If Abeline has died, the characters must search for the location themselves, finding it with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check.

When characters arrive, they realise why the place has its name. Accessing it via land requires a dangerous climb down a cliff. The cliff is 150 feet tall and requires a successful DC 18 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A character who fails the check must determine at what height they begin to slip, roll a {@dice d10} and multiply the result by 10. The character must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw, catching themselves on a success. On a failed save the character falls the remaining distance to the rocky cove, taking {@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Enter a number of dice to roll,default=1$#d6|1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen. Abeline knows a secret stair which can be used to descend safely.

When characters arrive in the cavern at Breakhand Cove, they can meet with Kraken Society members if they joined the cult; those who refused must remain behind. Each member of the meet conceals their identity with a black veil, but there are three {@creature noble|mm|nobles}, three {@creature cult fanatic|mm|cult fanatics}, and two concealed {@creature deep scion|vgm|deep scions} from Purple Rocks. The deep scions tell the gathered cultists whether the attack on Waterdeep (and the other cities) was successful and whether others are to take place (this is up to the DM).

Any suggestion that anything is wrong is met with jeers from the other members and curiosity from the deep scions. Characters who succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Persuasion}) check can get the scions to reveal that Purple Rocks is undergoing a change. The fish stocks are running low, so more and more sacrifices are being made to Slarkrethel. His organisation of attacks on the Sword Coast must surely be signs of his pleasure. If the characters search the possessions of the scions (by stealing them or killing the scions first) they discover letters from Sea King Tentrix.

entries.name: Uth'ivellios Cithrea's Quest
entries: Uth'ivellios Cithrea, leader of the sea elves, approaches the characters. Uth'ivellios is certain that there must be a malenti within their ranks. He asks the characters to search Tharqualnaar for the malenti. Uth'ivellios gives each character a magic item that should help them investigate the sunken city such as a {@item cap of water breathing}, a {@item cloak of the manta ray}, or a {@item ring of water walking}. If the characters already have such an item, have each player choose one item from {@table Magic Item Table B|dmg} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Development
entries: To discover the malenti in Tharqualnaar, the characters must engage in a Skill Challenge. The characters must succeed on three DC 15 ability checks before failing three checks to outsmart and capture the malenti. Allow any reasonable skill to be used, such as the following examples:

items: Strength ({@skill Intimidation}) check to lean on the inhabitants of the community for information
Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to spy on suspects
Constitution check to maintain composure in the depths of the ocean
Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check to help distinguish the subtleties between malenti and sea elf
Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check to see who might be lying about the infiltrator
Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check to coax information out of people about their neighbours

entries: If the characters win the skill challenge, they uncover Ilanquor the {@creature malenti|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) hiding out in the seedier areas of the city. They have the chance to capture Ilanquor and bring them back to Uth'ivellios for questioning.

If the characters lose the skill challenge, Ilanquor gets wind of the investigations and sets up a trap for them. While the characters are investigating the inhabitants of the seedier districts of Tharqualnaar, Ilanquor and two sea elf {@creature spy|mm|spies} he has allied with jump the characters. Ilanquor has summoned a {@creature giant shark} which arrives a round later.

If characters get to question Ilanquor, he gives up his information for his life. The pirate attacks were organised by Sea King Tentrix, a pirate king from the Nelanther Isles. This information can also be gathered from the Ilanquor's possessions (accessible by killing or stealing from him). This information should be enough to send the characters searching for Sea King Tentrix in the Nelanther Isles.

entries.name: Melessa Suaril's Quest
entries: The characters are sought out by an acolyte of the Priestess of High Moonlight. They escort the characters to the House of the Moon where the they meet with Melessa. She asks the characters to investigate a trio of weresharks who recently left the Silverstars; lycanthropes who serve {@deity Selûne|Faerûnian|scag} as elite warriors. Rumour has it they were recruited by a pirate crew out of Pandira of the Korinn Archipelago. If the characters return having convinced the weresharks to return it would be a boon to Selûne's army. Melessa gives the characters 200 gp for any information they can gather, or 1,000 gp if they return with the weresharks.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters sail to Pandira they quickly find out about the weresharks. Asking around in the shanty towns and rundown taverns reveals that the weresharks have joined the crew of the Blood Moon, a keelboat with a lycanthrope crew.

To track down the Blood Moon, the characters must succeed on either a DC 18 Wisdom (Survival) check to follow its trail, or a DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) or ({@skill Intimidation}) check to get information from locals. If the characters catch up with the Blood Moon it is attacking an Amnian merchant ship. The crew of the Blood Moon consists of three {@creature wererat|mm|wererats}, three {@creature wereshark|CallfromtheDeep|weresharks}, and a {@creature werewolf} captain. The crew of the Amnian vessel, the Copperskiff, are all {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} save for the {@creature noble} captain.

The characters can convince the weresharks to abandon piracy and return to the church of {@deity Selûne|Faerûnian|scag} with a successful DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. The characters have advantage on the check if they rouse memories of their previous lives; being a member of the Silverstars themselves, displaying holy symbols of Selûne, or succeeding on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Religion}) check.

entries.name: Sultan Klaptikos' Quest
entries: If the characters free Sultan Klaptikos from imprisonment, he asks a favour of the characters. Klaptikos remembers having a great seafaring vessel before he was caught and imprisoned by a Calishite wizard. He can't remember the exact nature of the ship though, nor where he stored it. This is because his memory was stolen by a yugoloth. He thinks the creature was working for his great rival, Sultana Papadopolis of the Sapphire Tempest who was always jealous of his ship. If the characters allow him, Sultan Klaptikos casts {@spell plane shift} to take the characters to the Elemental Plane of Water and track down the hydroloth.

entries.name: Development
entries: The characters arrive at the Isle of Dread in the Sea of Worlds. This rugged, tropical island is home to lost souls who were brought to the plane by accident and now scrape a living through piracy and trade. Klaptikos is certain the hydroloth is nearby, but this must be confirmed by locals. Klaptikos leads the characters to an inn called The Mermaid's Purse where they can investigation.

The Mermaid's Purse is an enormous, striped nautilus shell half-submerged beneath the waves, resting on a golden, palm-lined beach. The place is madness. All variety of creatures inhabit the place, drinking strong spiced rum and watered-down grog. The tavern interior is made up of chambers separated by iridescent, translucent walls. The owner of the establishment is an awakened {@creature killer whale} (with an Intelligence of 10 and the ability to speak {@language Common}) called Captain Clipper.
There are numerous ways for the characters to find out who the hydroloth is, and have them brought to the characters:

items: Captain Clipper is a total gossip. A successful DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check gets him to blab about yugoloths hiring themselves out of the tavern on a regular basis. He doesn't remember a specific hydroloth, but asking other mercenaries in the Coral Chamber of the tavern might prove useful.

entries: The Coral Chamber is an underwater room which contains a {@creature mezzoloth} mercenary in discussion with seedy looking pirates (five CE {@creature bandit captain|mm|bandit captains} of mixed race and gender led by a merfolk {@creature swashbuckler|vgm}). If characters interrupt the conversation, the pirates get hostile and threaten them. If characters defeat the pirates or succeed on a DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check, the mezzoloth is impressed and asks what they want. It reveals that a hydroloth named Oneiro is a well-known thought thief in the area. They'll likely drop by the tavern in the next few days.

The characters can hire the mezzoloth to capture Oneiro. It accepts gems worth 1,000 gp or more. Characters can barter them down to 750 gp with a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check.

items: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice an aldani {@creature assassin} spinning his coral-handled {@item dagger|phb|daggers} on the tips of her oversized claws. Characters who approach the lobsterfolk, known as Skittering Death, can pay her for information. A bribe of 100 gp gets Skittering Death to reveal that a hydroloth named Oneiro is responsible for Klaptikos' lost memory. Skittering Death kills Oneiro for 800 gp or brings him to the characters alive for 1,000 gp.

Sitting around a massive barrel drinking tankard after tankard of grog are three triton {@creature noble|mm|nobles} and their pet {@creature monkey|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The tritons are on the verge of passing out, but if characters get in quick and buy a round any questions about yugoloths for hire are responded to honestly. One of the tritons admits he hired a hydroloth named Oneiro from the Coral Chamber to wipe his own memory of a particularly raucous night.

After three days pass in the tavern (use the {@table random encounters; coast|CallfromtheDeep|Coastal random encounters} in appendix A), Oneiro the {@creature hydroloth|mtf} turns up at the Mermaid's Purse looking for work. It buys a rum then heads to the Coral Chamber. Unless the characters act immediately, it becomes wrapped up in a discussion with a {@creature sea hag} customer. Characters who fight Oneiro must also fight the hag, Sister Scumbucket.

entries: Eventually, characters get the chance to talk to Oneiro. Although the yugoloth fights the characters it doesn't want to return to Gehenna and gives over information if they spare its life. Oneiro was hired by Sultana Papadopolis to steal Sultan Klaptikos' memory of the ship. Papadopolis didn't want it herself, so beached the thing on the Material Plane on an island scattered with huge skeletons. Oneiro doesn't know the name of the place, but a successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check allows a character to remember The Whale Bones, islands west of Waterdeep, whose shores are scattered with their namesake.

After recovering this information, Klaptikos teleports himself and the characters to The Whale Bones. After spending a day searching the characters find the ship, the Flying Squid. Unfortunately, the ship has been breached by a gang of eight {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} led by Aslaug Waveborn (NE female Illuskan human {@creature gladiator} with disadvantage on {@skill Perception} checks and ranged attack rolls). Aslaug has thick, braided hair, a leather eyepatch, and wields a {@item Aslaug Waveborn's Spear|CallfromtheDeep|+1 spear} with the waterborne Minor Property (see {@table special features; what minor property does it have|dmg|Special Features} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). Characters have to fight the crew to get the ship back, although killing Aslaug causes the others to flee.

The Flying Squid is a {@item The Flying Squid|CallfromtheDeep|sailing ship} powered by a {@creature water elemental} which can be summoned by Sultan Klaptikos and bound to a gyroscopic adamantine prison in the hold. Successfully binding the elemental requires a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check which one of the characters can attempt after Klaptikos summons the elemental using the {@spell conjure elemental} spell. The ship is twice as fast as others of its ilk and only requires a crew of five.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: Characters gain levels in this chapter by completing the goals summarised below:

items: Characters who defend one of the Sword Coast cities advance to 6th level.
For each additional city defended, the characters may gain an additional level.
Characters who undertake additional quests have the chance to gain character levels at your discretion, advance one level per two quests as a rough guide.

entries.name: Chapter 3: Scouring the Seas
entries: A perilous coastline serves as the backdrop for this story. It transpires that the entirety of the Sword Coast and the Island Kingdoms are beset by pirates, the Kraken Society, with the mind flayers manipulating both. This chapter describes this setting, beginning with an overview of the Island Kingdoms and some of its key inhabitants, then presenting descriptions of specific locations. The chapter concludes with the characters discovering Sea King Tentrix's lair, a ship graveyard called Driftwood Docks in the Nelanther Isles.

Until the characters find a more expeditious means of transportation, they will be doing a lot of overland and overseas travel. {@book Chapter 5|dmg|5|Wilderness} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} provides advice and tools to help make wilderness travel fun for you and the players, as well as rules for foraging and becoming lost. You can use the travel-montage approach or the hour-by-hour approach, or you can experiment with both to see which approach works best for you. That chapter also includes a table to randomly determine the weather and a table of random urban encounters (useful when the adventurers arrive at a city).

entries.name: Folk of the Sword Coast
entries: West of the Sword Coast lies the Sea of Swords and beyond that the Trackless Sea, a vast expanse separating Faerûn from whatever lies to the far west. Between the shore and the unknown are a number of islands, some large and others so small they lack names of their own. These island nations make trade and war with Faerûn and one another just like any mainland nation.

Close to Faerûn are the Whalebones and Ruathym, ancient homes of the ancestors of the Illuskan people, and the Moonshaes where many of those same people now share the islands with the Ffolk and an elf offshoot known as the Llewyr. The free port of Mintarn lies nearby, a neutral site for meetings between enemies and a recruitment spot that offers abundant jobs for sailors. Despite its size, the tiny island of Orlumbor, with its treacherous harbour and its skilled, in-demand shipwrights, is an independent and influential nation unto itself. In the seas to the south, pirates of many races and predilections sail from the Nelanther Isles, preying on trade running north and south along the coast. Further to the north are the islands of Gundarlun, The Purple Rocks, and Tuern. Gundarlun is the only island member of the Lords' Alliance and boasts a powerful navy called the Kingsfleet which is busy defending the coast from pirates. Tuern is a violent place of tribal warfare and raiding, like many other Northlander isles. The Purple Rocks, a gathering of small islands ruled by native kings, pays homage to the kraken Slarkrethel. Their lives are defined by their worship of King of the Trackless Depths.

entries.name: Civilised Folk
entries: Humans are the most widespread of the civilised races, but no unified human nation exists on the Sword Coast, only individual cities, towns, villages, fiefdoms, farmsteads, fortresses, and outposts connected to one another by long, mostly unprotected rivers and roads. Human settlements rely on various industries for survival including fishing, mining, and farming. Coastal cities are home to human traders, shipbuilders, and artisans.

Although each city of the Sword Coast enjoys and maintains its independence, all these communities are at risk of being overrun by the monstrous threats that live outside their walls. Fear of the wilderness and its many terrors led to the formation of the Lords' Alliance, a loose confederacy of human-dominated settlements built on mutually beneficial trade agreements and a willingness to seek out and destroy threats to civilization. Members of the Lords' Alliance include the cities of Waterdeep, Neverwinter, Baldur's Gate, and the island of Gundbarg.

Within the settlements of the Sword Coast one can find humans, dwarves, elves, and other civilised races commingling more or less peacefully. Waterdeep, in particular, is a melting pot of races from all over Faerûn. Outside of these communities, however, people have much less tolerance for other races, as folk tend to feel safer among their own kind. Small towns and villages dominated by humans tend to have few, if any, non-humans, with most dwarves, elves, and halflings preferring to live in their own settlements, far from human-claimed lands. In generations past, most human settlers of the Island Kingdoms were fair-haired and light-skinned. Since then, the riches and promise of the islands have attracted folk from other regions, and several generations of cultural mingling has given the humans of Faerûn much greater diversity in their appearance (see "{@footnote {@race human|phb|Human Names and Ethnicities}|See the {@i Info} tab of the {@race human} race.}" in chapter 2 of the {@i Player's Handbook}).

entries.name: Northlanders
entries: The terms Northlander, Norls, Northfolk, and Northmen are interchangeable. They refer to one of several tall, fairhaired, seagoing peoples that ply the cold northern waters and dwell on the islands of the west including Tuern, Gundarlun, Ruathym, the Purple Rocks, and the Korinn Archipelago.
