Northfolk ancestors built small villages along the Sword Coast that have since become cities, including fabled Illusk (now Luskan), Eigersstor (now Neverwinter), and Nimoar's Hold (now Waterdeep). These early Northlanders farmed the rocky coastlines, fished coastal waters, and hunted seals and whales on the open sea.

Although Northlanders are often called barbarians, not all of them fit this description. Along the Sword Coast, some tribes have become fairly civilised, primarily due to the growth of the coastal cities and the increasing influence of outsiders. These people farm, fish, and mine their rugged lands, then shrewdly trade their goods with foreign buyers. Many once-feared tribes have become merchants whose bartering skills are equal to or better than the warlike talents of their ancestors, such that many a Northlander merchant earns more booty than their raiding neighbours. In many cases, however, the Northlanders of the Island Kingdoms still uphold the raiding and reaving culture of their past. Longships filled with berserkers loyal to one king set out over the waves to find new islands to plunder. Those who return with the finest goods and the biggest scars tend to become the next kings.

entries.name: Ffolk
entries: The Ffolk of the Moonshae Isles are descended from Tethyrian settlers who came to the islands a thousand years ago. The Ffolk have a deep respect for nature and are primarily farmers, worshiping the goddess they call the Earthmother and keeping to old druidic ways. Ffolk shipwrights are well regarded, having proven their ability to build sturdy ships that are capable of weathering the tumultuous seas around their home. The leader of the Ffolk is High King Derid Kendrick, who rules from the fortress of Caer Callidyr on Alaron. Despite their official ruler, the Ffolk are not the kind to be bound by society, and the druids of the woods and mountains pay little heed to the High King's court.

entries.name: Orcs and Half-Orcs
entries: The history of the North is replete with tales of orc hordes spilling out of the mountains to attack the mines, ranches, farmsteads, and settlements of other folk. When a particularly strong orc chieftain unites multiple tribes under one banner, the resulting horde typically rampages across the land, laying waste to strongholds and slaughtering other creatures in its path. Civilised communities form their own coalitions to combat rampaging orcs, with mixed results.

Not all orc chieftains are bent on destruction: King Obould Many-Arrows forged a tenuous alliance with his dwarf neighbours and helped maintain peace in the Silver Marches during his tumultuous reign. Some of the Many-Arrows orcs invaded Neverwinter during its time of troubles and still reside in the Tower District today. Half-orcs in the North are often burdened with the evil reputation of their orc cousins. It takes a half-orc of great character to step out of the shadow of evil and live as an equal among the civilised races.

entries.name: Shield Dwarves
entries: Shield dwarves (also known as mountain dwarves) have a number of strongholds along the Sword Coast including Ironmaster, Thornhold, and Gauntlgrym. Shield dwarves can also be found in smaller communities in the Island Kingdoms such as the Ironstar dwarves of Mintarn, and scattered clans in the Moonshae Isles. Few non-dwarves live in these bastions of dwarvenkind. Outside their walls, clans of shield dwarves are spread thinly throughout the Sword Coast, to the extent that it's hard to find a settlement that doesn't include at least a handful of dwarven residents.

entries.name: Elves
entries: Sun elves and moon elves, like dwarves, live among humans in settlements throughout the Sword Coast. The elven kingdoms of old are distant memories even to elves, and only a few ancient ruins and relics of these kingdoms survive. Dangerous and xenophobic wood elves are known to haunt certain forests along the Sword Coast. Few elves live out in the Island Kingdoms, save for the Llewyrr elves of the Moonshaes. They hail from the kingdom of Synnoria on the isle of Gwynneth. The Llewyrr are a mix of wood and moon elves, descended perhaps from a fleet on their way to Evermeet. They are often vegetarian and act as wardens over the animals of Myrloch Vale. The elves here mix freely with dwarves and humans so long as they are respectful of the wildlife.

entries.name: Halflings
entries: Small populations of lightfoot halflings can be found in most human-dominated settlements of the Sword Coast. Scattered throughout the fertile valleys of the North are small clusters of strongheart halfling homesteads, some of which spread into the lands of the Sword Coast. Halfling homesteads tend to be off the beaten path and well hidden, minimising the halflings' contact with bandits, barbarians, and marauding monsters. It's not unusual to see a quaint hamlet of halfling homesteads nestled in a grassy ravine or along the shore of a river. There are no large halfling communities in the Island Kingdoms, but families of more adventurous small-folk have emigrated overseas for a shot at a new life.

entries.name: Random Encounters
entries: While the characters are moving throughout the Sword Coast and Island Kingdoms they are likely to encounter wandering monsters. You should use the information in {@adventure Appendix A: Random Encounters|CallfromtheDeep|11} to help you manage the characters travel.

entries.name: Locations in the Island Kingdoms & Sword Coast
entries: The locations described in this section appear on the {@adventure Sword Coast map|CallfromtheDeep|0|Sword Coast Map} in this chapter. Additional information on several of these places can be found in the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag}. Not depicted on the map are scores of tiny hamlets on the Sword Coast and dozens of tiny, unnamed islands scattered throughout the Island Kingdoms. These places are too small to be of consequence. Even so, adventurers traveling along a road or a trail might come across a tiny settlement consisting of a handful of homesteads built around an inn or tavern where locals gather. (If you need a tavern name, use the {@table Random Buildings; Tavern name Generator|dmg|Tavern Name Generator} table in chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.)

Some location entries include a suggested encounter that occurs when the characters first arrive or shortly thereafter. You can ignore the encounter and create your own activity based on the information given in a location's description; for example, the "{@area Alaron|alaron|x}" section mentions evil fey creatures in the Dernal Forest, which might make for a fun encounter of your own creation. For the most part, the suggested encounters push the main narrative of Call from the Deep, helping you to keep your players interested in the campaign while they explore Faerûn.

entries.name: Sidebar: Water Pressure
entries: Some locations beneath the ocean are so deep that water pressure becomes a problem. Creatures and vehicles at a depth of 3,000 feet or lower take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage per minute from water pressure unless they are adapted or built to withstand this environment. Storm giants, whales, sharks, crustaceans, and aquatic invertebrates are immune to water pressure at this depth, as are vehicles with a damage threshold of 10 or higher.

Other creatures might be immune to the effect of water pressure at your discretion. Typically, a magic item that gives its wearer the ability to breathe water also protects it from deep-sea pressures.

entries.name: Alaron
entries: The largest and most populous isle of the Moonshaes is Alaron. The Ffolk stronghold of Caer Callidyr overlooks a bay south of the Fairheight Mountains, at the northern edge of Dernal Forest. The forest is a perilous place, filled with goblins, worgs, and their ilk. The deeper one goes, the more otherworldly the woods become, with fey creatures leading travellers astray, or to their doom. Even the High King's rangers walk the forest with care. The Fairheight Mountains are occupied by the Rookoath clan of dwarves, who have recently driven out a shadow dragon from the Dernal Forest with Clan Rustfire of Gwynneth. On the Great South Head of Alaron is a port town called Kythyss, which has been hiring mercenaries to guard caravans running north to Callidyr.

Alaron is ruled by High King Derid Kendrick (NG male Tethyrian human {@creature noble}) who lives in Caer Callidyrr, the capital city of the Ffolk people on the Moonshaes. The great Castle Callidyrr is constructed from huge blocks of alabaster. The Ffolk of Alaron are welcoming to other civilised peoples, and to a lesser extent to peaceful Norls.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Adventurers who visit Alaron are quickly noticed by caravan owners from the Great South Head and asked to visit the small fishing city of Kythyss. The city is being forced to hire Amnian mercenaries to protect the sea lane between Caer Callidyrr and Kythyss from pirates. The harbourmaster of Kythyss, Thedarra Talmerrin (LN female Tethyrian human {@creature thug}), asks the characters to escort a {@item keelboat|CallfromtheDeep} called the Silvery Horn between the cities.
If the characters express interest in the work, Thedarra shares the following information:

items: Scouts patrolling the eastern coast of Alaron ahve reported sightings of merrow along the shore.
A spellcasting merrow, known as a merroni, attacked a trade ship two days ago.

If the characters can get the Silvery Horn to Caer Callidyrr safely they'll be awarded 250 gp and a {@item Quaal's feather token, swan boat} by the captain of the ship, Travok Rookoath (N male shield dwarf {@creature bandit captain}).
The Silvery Horn is a {@item cog|CallfromtheDeep} boat with a crew of eight {@creature commoner|mm|commoners}. It holds 40 tons of salted fish.

entries: Characters who accept the quest must accompany the Silvery Horn, either on board or in a nearby ship, for the 250-mile journey north from Kythyss to Caer Callidyrr. Check for {@table random encounters; sea|CallfromtheDeep|random encounters} as normal during the journey.

Around the 100-mile mark, as the characters pass the rocky coastline of Rushdown Wood, the Silvery Horn is attacked by eight {@creature merrow} and a {@creature merroni|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) with a {@item wand of web}. The merrow harpoon crew members overboard or clamber onto the ship, while the merroni assaults the ships and crew with spells from a distance. If the merroni is threatened, the merrow fight to the death protecting it.

If the battle turns against the merrow, the merroni flees south. Characters who pursue the merroni and succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check realise it is fleeing toward the Nelanther Isles. Characters who capture the merroni can interrogate it for information. If they succeed on a DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check the merroni reveals that it is part of a huge network of pirates working for Sea King Tentrix.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who kill the merrow and their merroni leader can plunder the {@item wand of web}, eight 50 gp gems in a leather pouch, and a scrap of sodden parchment depicting a route to an island surrounded by swirling water. This is a drawing of the route in and out of Driftwood Docks, a notoriously dangerous island in the Nelanthers. Characters from the Nelanthers instantly recognise it, as do those who succeed on a DC 25 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check. Characters with a nautical background have advantage on the check.

entries.name: Ardeep Forest
entries: This forest east of Waterdeep and the Dessarin River was once part of the long-lost elven kingdom of Illefarn. Now, it is home to a small clan of wood elves recently arrived from Evermeet. They refuse to leave their woods, guarding relics and ruins of ages past, and they want nothing to do with the world beyond their borders.

entries.name: Asavir's Channel
entries: The stretch of water between the Nelanther Isles and Dragon's Head, the Tethyrian peninsula, is known as Asavir's Channel. The strait is named after a notorious pirate king from centuries past who used to plunder Amnian vessels relentlessly as they travelled through. The waterway is no better today and any ship risking the journey is almost certain to be attacked by raiders from the Nelanthers. Recently, the strait has been harassed not only by pirates but by an undead dragon turtle known as the Curse of Irphong.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The first time characters enter Asavir's Channel in a seafaring vessel they are attacked by a {@creature zombie dragon turtle|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep}). Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice the immense beast rising from beneath the waves directly beneath the ship. If the characters notice the dragon turtle, the crew can avoid it with a successful DC 15 group Dexterity check. Otherwise, the dragon turtle slams into the bottom of the ship dealing 62 ({@damage 5d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage to it.

The dragon turtle has no interest in killing the crew, only sinking the ship on behalf of its master (see the "{@area Sea Tower of Irphong|sea tower of irphong|x}" section). If the boat is sunk, a pirate crew of thirty {@creature skeleton|mm|skeletons} on a {@item sailing ship|CallfromtheDeep} called Day's End comes to collect any survivors. They take all survivors to the Sea Tower of Irphong, and from there to Driftwood Docks.

entries.name: Ascarle
entries: Ascarle is a sunken elven city located off the northern shores of Trisk in the Purple Rocks. The underwater settlement is the lair of Slarkrethel the kraken but has since been occupied by Zellix'Phor and its mind flayer colony. See {@adventure chapter 5|CallfromtheDeep|9} "{@footnote Lair of Zellix'Phor|This section doesn't exist.}" for more information.

entries.name: Aulmyr
entries: Beneath the waves lies Aulmyr, a merfolk settlement in a deep-sea trench around 3,000 feet down. Aulmyr is located in the heart of a kelp forest, making it unnoticeable except from above. The city itself consists of dozens of huge, vibrantly coloured anemones and sponges which have been hollowed out and fitted with floors and rooms. Much like an overground settlement, the city has different locales and attractions. Different wards of the city harbour different trades and house different folk. The majority of the settlement is occupied by merfolk, though there are a few neighbourhoods of tritons and sea elves, and even a monastery in the lower reaches of the city that is home exclusively to aldani.

Aulmyr is a plutocracy, ruled by a wealthy merchant class who buy their place in the court of Chieftain Nissailin Southsea (LN non-binary merfolk {@creature noble} wielding a {@item trident|phb}) for 25 gp a month. These tithes are collected by merfolk {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} in an enormous, engraved calm shell.

Recently, Aulmyr has been plagued by strange visitors from the west, humanoids with piscine mutations that appear in their anemone homes during hours of rest. One of the tritons in Nissailin's court named Belthyn Vuuxariath (NE female triton) is a {@creature deep scion|vgm}, though keeps their true identity a secret. They were transformed by Slarkrethel to keep an eye on Aulmyr. It is because of Belthyn that visitors keep arriving in the city. They steal from the merfolk community on their way to the Sword Coast.

Characters can stay in numerous places in Aulmyr including taverns which serve fresh shellfish and fleshy pouches of fermented roe. They might instead seek luxury in the Southsea Court, sanctuary in the lobsterfolk monastery, or simply sleep rough in the kelp forest.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The first time characters take a long rest in Aulmyr they awaken in the middle of their slumber to see dark shapes moving about their chambers. Belthyn has informed the Kraken Society of their presence in the city and has sent a detachment of ten {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} and six {@creature deep scion|vgm|deep scions} to assassinate them. The group splits in half, and each group tries to surprise a different character in their sleep.
Characters who defeat and interrogate the creatures can get some limited information about Slarkrethel:

items: The Kraken Society has agents in the city, the most influential is the triton Belthyn Vuuxariath.
The characters are being hunted by the Kraken Society for interfering with their plans.

The sea spawn don't know who the head of the Kraken Society is, but the deep scions do. They reveal this information if a character succeeds on a DC 17 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, they also reveal that Slarkrethel lairs in Ascarle, north of Purple Rocks.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each deep scion carries a pouch containing {@dice 2d10} gp.

entries.name: Aurilssbarg
entries: See the "{@area Ice Peak|ice peak|x}" section.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: Baldur's Gate is a prominent city on the Sword Coast. See chapter 2 "{@adventure Baldur's Gate|CallfromtheDeep|4}" or the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag} for more information on this location.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Unless it has already occurred, you can run the "{@adventure Attack on Baldur's Gate|CallfromtheDeep|4|Attack on Baldur's Gate}" encounter (see chapter 2) when the characters visit the city.

entries.name: Bryn Shander
entries: Bryn Shander is the largest of ten settlements, known collectively as Ten-Towns, located in the frigid heart of lcewind Dale. Here caravans from the south converge with traders from across the dale to swap goods and rumours. Fishers, trappers, furriers, and sellswords rub elbows in the town's taprooms, and gruff dwarves, wide-eyed travellers, and skulking ne'er-do-wells wander its streets. Merchants from the south trade dyes, hardwood, dried herbs and spices, textiles, fruits, wines, and other commodities for scrimshaw and other items made from the bones of the knucklehead trout that populate the region's waterways.

The town is situated atop a hill south of the mountain known as Kelvin's Cairn, a major landmark in Icewind Dale. From its windswept perch, Bryn Shander has a commanding view of the surrounding tundra, and an attacking force must climb the barren hillside under fire from archers before it can assault the outer wall. The circular wall that surrounds Bryn Shander stands 30 feet high and is made of tight-fitting stone blocks. Defenders stand atop a planked walkway that hugs the interior of the wall. Spaced along the wall are stone watchtowers, wherein guards can take shelter during blizzards and warm their hands and feet by iron stoves. The buildings of Bryn Shander are plain wooden structures with pitched rooftops to keep snow from settling on them. Clouds of white smoke issue forth day and night from stone chimneys.

Each community in Ten-Towns has an elected speaker who leads the residents and represents their interests. The current speaker of Bryn Shander is Duvessa Shane (LG female Illuskan human {@creature noble}). She has appointed Markham Southwell (LG male Turami human {@creature veteran}) as her sheriff, making him responsible for training the town's militia (good-aligned male and female {@creature guard|mm|guards} of various ethnicities) and keeping the peace.

entries.name: Caer Allisynn
entries: This majestic, underwater castle was built by an old High King of the Moonshaes for his beloved wife, who perished during a war over a century ago. While Caer Allisynn is normally an underwater realm, it occasionally rises from the ocean to bask in the glorious sun when the weather is right. There is a 10 percent chance that the castle has risen above the waves when the characters visit. The castle is located between the islands of Norland, Alaron, and Oman's Isle in the relatively shallow Sea of Moonshae.

Characters who wish to reach the castle can do so by swimming down just off the bay of Oman's Isle, which is around 100 feet deep. On days when the water is clear, the vague outline of the castle can be seen beneath the waves.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters might wish to plunder the tomb of Queen Allisynn for the trove of treasure that she was buried with. If they are able to swim down to the entrance to Caer Allisynn, there is nothing to stop them entering the tomb.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Caer Allisynn (Player).png}.}

Behind the enormous oaken doors of the submerged castle is a display of grandeur. The castle must be magically protected from the ravages of the ocean in some way as, despite the salty water which fills it, the grand hall ahead looks as it must have done over a century ago. Fine tapestries line the walls depicting argent unicorns in verdant forests, raucous satyr in revelry and a beautiful, silver-haired woman with strong features surrounded by tiny winged fey.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This room is empty but sounds made in here, such as the furling tapestries, gather the attention of the scrags in {@area c2|ca2}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The enormous tapestries are worth 1,500 gp each but are easily recognised by Ffolk, Llewyrr elves, and dwarves from the Moonshaes. Taking a tapestry from the wall triggers a {@spell conjure fey} spell, which summons a {@creature yeth hound|vgm}. The hound attacks the characters, and alerts the scrags on {@area c2|ca2}.
Rising high above the rest of the castle are two pointed towers dotted with arrow slits. Inside, their interior walls and spiral stairs have been sculpted with floral patterns in alabaster.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Each tower contains a {@creature scrag|CallfromtheDeep}, which uses the statistics of a {@creature troll} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: Scrags have a swim speed of 30 feet.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: The scrag can breathe air and water.

items.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it is fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag only dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.
If the scrags hear movement in {@area c1|ca1}, they leave this area to investigate.

Resting on a raised dais in the centre of this chamber is a coffin made of jade-tinted glass with gilded edges. Etched across the surface are exquisite flowering vines. Standing in the corners of the chamber are suits of armour enamelled in green and white, their hands resting on greatswords whose blades resemble slender leaves.

entries.name: Coffin
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell cast on the coffin reveals an aura of abjuration magic. Inside the coffin is the body of a woman. Characters who entered through {@area c1|ca1} immedaitely recognise her from the tapestry there. Any humanoid remains placed inside the coffin do not degrade and can't become undead by any means short of a {@spell wish} spell. The coffin can only be opened with a {@spell knock} spell and must be resealed with an {@spell arcane lock} spell.

entries.name: Queen Allisynn
entries: Creatures who steal anything from Caer Allisynn cause a {@spell speak with dead} effect to occur on the Queen's corpse. She asks why the characters would steal from her tomb and beseeches them to return anything they have taken, as they were gifts from her husband High King Cymrych Hugh. If characters explain that they are using the items to fight off a threat to the Realms, and promise to return the tiems, they can attempt a DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. On a success the Queen lets them take the items. On a failure the Queen spits a fey curse at the characters, causing the suits of armour to animate and attack. See Fey Queen's Curse in {@area c4|ca4}.
The Queen's Corpse can be destroyed by dealing any damage to it once the coffin has been opened. Destroying her corpse ends any curse she has placed on the characters.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Queen Allisynn can animate the suits of armour in this chamber. The four suits of {@creature animated armor|mm|animated armour} each wield a {@item greatsword|phb} ({@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) slashing damage on a hit).

entries.name: C4. The Queen's Trove
entries: The doors to this area are locked but can be opened with a successful DC 20 Strength check, or a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.
Stands of weapons, suits of armour, and cases filled with fine treasures line the walls of these chambers. Each item seems to glisten as if recently polished.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: There is a wealth of treasure in this room:

items: A necklace of iridescent purple pearls (2,500 gp)
An oaken {@item quarterstaff|phb} inlaid with tiny emeralds (1,500 gp)
Three silk cloaks with knot motifs (750 gp each)
A silver brooch in the shape of a unicorn (500 gp)
Assorted jewellery and gems (1,500 gp)
A {@item figurine of wondrous power, ivory goats}
A {@item ring of cold resistance}
A pair of {@item gloves of missile snaring}

entries: Any character that takes an item from area c4 without gaining the Queen's permission (see {@area c3|ca3}) becomes cursed, a fact only revealed by casting an {@spell identify} spell on the items. The {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic ends the curse, as does destroying the corpse of Queen Allisynn.

While cursed, a creature is plagued by fey creatures. At the start of each long rest, roll a {@dice d20}. On a result of 15 or higher, the creature is attacked by a {@filter fey creature|bestiary|type=fey} or creatures relevant to the environment they are in.
This tower spirals like the horn of a unicorn. Inside it are dozens of bird figures carved from various woods in amazing, lifelike detail.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: There are thirty-five wooden bird figurines in the tower (25 gp each). Speaking the name of the bird variety causes the wooden figurine to sing a song akin to that of its living counterpart.

entries.name: Candlekeep
entries: Candlekeep stands on a volcanic crag around a hundred feet from the coastline; a flat-topped spur of rough stone out in the midst of the surging sea. The top of this crag is hemmed in entirely by a tall wall, interrupted by several towers, which enclose a large space from which more towers rise. The mist of sea-spray fills the air nearest the western walls and in winter this moisture causes treacherous build-ups of ice. Sometimes entire towers along the western edge are abandoned for the season, they become so overtaken by frost.

From the centre of the enclosed area rises the largest and thickest tower of Candlekeep. About this central keep a garden spirals in rising steps, and those lucky enough to enter the library proper do so by passing around and up through this green space to the keep's main door. However, most folk who visit Candlekeep see this structure only from the courtyard east of it, where the facilities for arriving scholars lie.

The only gate into Candlekeep stands at the end of the Way of the Lion; the only road providing access to and from the outside world. The route extends from Beregost, leagues away, and winds a lonely path out to the peninsula where Candlekeep stands.

Characters might end up in Candlekeep should they accept {@area Ramazith Flamesinger's Quest|bgqrfq|x} in chapter 2. Otherwise, access is only granted to those who bring a work of writing not already in possession of the monks of Candlekeep. Thankfully, Ramazith has a tome of marine ecology which he can present, but the characters might need to search for their own should they come without him.

If characters gain access to Candlekeep they can use its great library to help research almost any topic. They are able to discover more information about any of the Island Kingdoms, including the Nelanther Isles and Purple Rocks. If the characters are looking for shady information they might not find in a book, they can get in contact with Steamy Pete (N male Chondathan human {@creature apprentice wizard|vgm}), a young scribe known as a source of illicit information. Steamy earned his nickname thanks to a scald scar that runs across his left arm. He makes up a different story for the wound each time he's asked. The exact nature of the information characters can gather is up to the DM.

entries.name: Cloakwood
entries: Around fifty miles north of Candlekeep is a thick, ancient, forest called Cloakwood. This forest is filled with fey and monsters that deter sensible folk from visiting the beautiful, rugged landscape within. The forest is slashed with streamcut ravines heading toward the cliffs that are shaded by tall specimens of beech, elm, and white pine. The variety of flora and fauna is stunning, enhanced by their isolation.

Unknown to most is that the cliffs of Cloakwood are puckered with smugglers coves and hidden caverns. One of these, known as Breakhand Cove, has become a regular meeting place for high-ranking members of the Kraken Society. Characters might visit this location if they accept {@area Dread High Trident Abeline Nerovarco's Quest|wdqanq|x} in chapter 2.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters who travel along the coastline of Cloakwood, either by foot or ship, hear echoed chanting emerging from one of the sea caves set into the high cliffs. Outside the cave, beached in a small cove, is a keelboat. The boat is empty save for three 10-foot lengths of chain. If the characters investigate they discover a group of Kraken Society cultists in the throes of a sanguine ceremony. The group consists of three {@creature cultist|mm|cultists} and two {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} and led by a {@creature Deep Scion Cultist Leader|CallfromtheDeep|deep scion} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: The deep scion wears a bronze, kraken embossed {@item breastplate|phb} (AC 15).
The deep scion has 80 hit points.

The deep scion wields a {@item +1 dagger} instead of a {@item battleaxe|phb}: {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 7 ({@damage 1d4 + 5}) slashing damage on a hit. The dagger is permanently rusty.
The deep scion has a challenge rating of 4 (1,100 XP).

entries: The two berserkers are holding down three {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} while the cultists chant and the scion repeatedly dips their rusty blade into the seawater the fills the first foot of the cave. Unless the characters intervene, the scion slashes the throats of the commoners and uses the bloody water to anoint the closed eyes of the cultists.

If the characters attack the deep scion, it undergoes a hideous transformation. Its skin blotches with patches of blue-black bruising which spreads to cover its entire body, its fingers become claw-like and webbed, fins and tentacles pierce its skin, and its cheeks peel open revealing row upon row of serrated teeth. Any character that sees the transformation must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain a random form of short-term madness, determined by rolling on the {@table Short-Term Madness} table in {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

The commoners are Amnian fishers. Their boat was capsized by a giant octopus and they were plucked out the water by the cult, chained up, and brought here. If the characters can return the fisherfolk to {@area Murann|murann|x} they are rewarded with 100 gp by the Harbour Guard.

entries.name: Cloud Peaks
entries: This small but incredibly tall mountain range stands on the border between the Sword Coast and of Amn. Despite its height, the range is relatively easy to traverse thanks to numerous ravines cut through the peaks. The Trade Way follows one of these called Fang Pass. The biggest threat to travellers here are {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} and {@creature hill giant|mm|hill giants} who have numerous outposts in the highest reaches, and the terrifying {@creature remorhaz} that ambush travellers in the passes by burrowing through the snow and bursting up beneath their feet.

entries.name: Daggerford
entries: Built on a hillside in the floodplain of the Delimbiyr River, the walled town of Daggerford is dominated by a three-story keep that belongs to its duchess Morwen Daggerford (LN female Tethyrian human {@creature veteran}). From atop Daggerford's walls dozens of farms and a scattering of hamlets are visible, all under the protection of the Lords' Alliance.

Until recently, Duchess Daggerford had been captured by Baroness Wynne Cromm in Cromm's Hold near the Lizard Marsh and replaced by a deceptive succubus named Pencheska. Thankfully, a band of adventurers uncovered the plot and reinstated Morwen as the rightful ruler of Daggerford. Removing the succubus also severed Daggerford's ties to the Black Network, leaving it without a militia and open to attack.

Around a tenday ago a gang of pirates made their way up the Delimbiyr River and into the town. They raided taverns and noble houses, kidnapped citizens, and stole precious treasures. Thoroughly shaken by the attack, the Duchess became desperate and grabbed hold of the first sign of help, a noblewoman from Waterdeep called Aisha Goldor (NE female Bedine human {@creature noble}) and her private army of twenty {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} known as the Goldor Arms.

Aisha is a member of the Kraken Society and is slowly gaining power over the Duchess, turning Daggerford into a safe haven for Krakenar on the Sword Coast. If the characters are searching for a specific member of the Kraken Society who is fleeing from them, such as Finnan Undergallow (see the "{@area Thornhold|thornhold|x}" section), Druette the Raven (see the "{@area Luskan|luskan|x}" section), or Jasper Littlefellow (see the "{@area Port Llast|port llast|x}" section), there is a strong chance they end up in Daggerford, protected by the Goldor Arms.

entries.name: Dragonspear Castle
entries: This crumbling, ruined castle is continually shrouded by a thick mist which permits only the vague outline of the derelict fort to be seen. Though it may seem like a sheltered spot to camp, Dragonspear Castle is actually one of the more dangerous locales of the Sword Coast. The fort is the site of numerous battles against devils and undead, who have assaulted Dragonspear on multiple occasions throughout its history.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters who explore the castle can clearly see the signs of warfare around the ruins. Skeletons clad in armour litter the courtyards, abandoned weapons remain stuck in the earth of greens, and bloodstains remain in chambers protected from the elements.
If the characters decide to rest here, roll a {@dice d20}:

items: On a roll of 1–5, nothing happens.
On a roll of 6–10, the characters are attacked by three {@creature spined devil|mm|spined devils} who fly out the unclosed infernal portal in the depths of the castle.
On a roll of 11–20, the characters are attacked by four {@creature shadow|mm|shadows} who attempt to drain their strength as they rest.

entries.name: Driftwood Docks
entries: Located on a western atoll of the Nelanthers, Driftwood Docks is a stretch of water notorious for scuppering and beaching ships. The rapid, ripping currents pull ships in from half a mile away and smash them against hidden reefs and rocky outcroppings. So many vessels have been wrecked here that the place resembles a ship graveyard, with towering hulls and forecastles lining the waterways.

Driftwood Docks is home to Sea King Tentrix's floating lair, the base of the Black Armada. See "{@adventure Pirate Kings & Kraken Priests|CallfromtheDeep|8}" for information on uncovering this location, and "{@adventure Driftwood Docks|CallfromtheDeep|8|Driftwood Docks}" in chapter 4 for a full description.

entries.name: Endless Ice
entries: This enormous glacier north of the Spine of the World is perhaps one of the bleakest areas in the North. The ice sheet seems to stretch on forever and is haunted only by the most rugged of arctic monstrosities.

entries.name: Evermoors
entries: The Evermoors is a vast, unsettled area of fog-shrouded hills, cold bogs, rocky ridges, and small peaks. Adventurers crossing this expanse might spot the occasional ruined castle or crumbled tower—the remnants of a bygone realm. Although the region attracts many prospectors, no kingdom or civilisation in recent history has been able to tame it. Savage {@creature hill giant|mm|hill giants}, {@creature ettin|mm|ettins}, {@creature ogre|mm|ogres}, {@creature orc|mm|orcs}, and {@creature troll|mm|trolls} dwell here in great numbers. Settlements on the edge of the Evermoors face constant threats from these monsters.

entries.name: Fields of the Dead
entries: The Fields of the Dead is a vast, rolling plain of windswept grasses that seems to stretch to the horizon in every direction. The wind constantly blows here, and noise of the stirring grass is often referred to as the 'whispers of the dead'. The grassland is dotted with hillocks and barrows which contain dead soldiers of one of dozens of wars fought on these lands. Thankfully there is hospitality here too; the local farmers are often kind and generous, offering some respite from roving monsters and bandits that lair in the plain, or the nearby Trollclaws and Wood of Sharp Teeth.

entries.name: Fireshear
entries: Long ago, a meteor strike blasted a crater in the frozen tundra near the coast of the Trackless Sea, shearing away tons of rock and exposing rich veins of ore. In the years that followed, miners settled nearby giving rise to the town of Fireshear. The miners work for a consortium of three allied merchant companies: Hammaver House of Mirabar, the Silver Triangle of Neverwinter, and the Delvers of Brokenstone of Waterdeep. The settlement is made up of squat stone structures that resemble igloos, their domes good at supporting the weight of snow and deflecting the cold wind. Most homes are dug out of the rock and include deep cellars laden with preserves.

The miners of Fireshear dwell here all year. Ramps carved into the cliffs lead down to the shore where stone docks protrude into a shallow bay that freezes by late fall and doesn't thaw until early summer. Fireshear imports most of its food, clothing, and other necessities. Ice fishing is a popular pastime among children, but all able-bodied adults are expected to toil in the mines.

The town has three leaders who form a ruling triumvirate that handles trade negotiations with representatives of other settlements and disperses supplies among the townsfolk. Each member is a representative of one of the town's founding companies. Triumvirate members serve for life or until they resign. They are known to take bribes, rewarding families who pay them in coin or precious ore with supplies of higher quality or quantity. The current members are Tharkus Gromm (NE male shield dwarf {@creature thug}) of Hammaver House; {@creature Darva|CallfromtheDeep} (NG female copper dragonborn {@creature mage}) of the Silver Triangle; and Zalaron Daska (N male Tethyrian human {@creature veteran}) of the Delvers of Brokenstone.

Fireshear is also home to a retired civilar of Waterdeep's Griffon Cavalry and member of the Emerald Enclave Dasharra Keldabar (LG female shield dwarf {@creature veteran}). She lives north of town in a mostly underground hovel on a ridge overlooking the sea. Locals know that Dasharra raises griffons, trains them as mounts, and teaches people to ride them. The {@creature griffon|mm|griffons} are kept in a low, sturdy wooden shelter next to her home. At any time, Dasharra has {@dice 1d4 + 6} adult griffons and {@dice 1d4} griffon eggs in her care. Dasharra employs six Zhentarim mercenaries (N male and female Tethyrian human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}) as guards, three of whom stand watch outside the griffon pens while the others rest in a cramped loft above the griffons' stalls.

If one or more characters are members of the Emerald Enclave or members of Waterdeep's Griffon Cavalry, they can easily convince Dasharra to help them fly to Luskan, Neverwinter, Gundarlun or some other destination within a few hundred miles of Fireshear. Otherwise, they must pay for her services. She charges 250 gp per person for training and another 25 gp per person per day of travel. Characters who want to be trained must undergo three days of intense lessons, after which they know enough about griffon riding to control their mounts. Each griffon can carry one Medium rider or two Small riders (along with their armour and portable gear). Dasharra's "alpha griffon," Screecher, allows only her to ride it. Dasharra's other griffons are trained to follow Screecher wherever it goes and can't be coaxed into veering off course unless they are magically {@condition charmed}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Three days after characters arrive in Fireshear, the town is assaulted by sahuagin and Luzgrigaul. The attack begins suddenly, as twenty {@creature sahuagin} equipped with {@item flensing claws (medium)|vgm|flensing claws}, eight {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep|sahuagin raiders} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and a {@creature sahuagin baron} equipped with a {@item mind blade|vgm} and wearing {@item mind carapace armor|vgm|mind carapace armour}, leap from the ocean onto the town's piers. The split into smaller groups of four or five to raid the miner's homes. The baron and two raiders knock people {@condition unconscious} and drag their bodies to the shore for Luzgrigaul.

As townsfolk flee to the mines or across the open tundra, Dasharra becomes aware of the attack and provides aerial support, attacking the with her {@item heavy crossbow|phb} from Screecher. If the baron is killed, the sahuagin retreat.

After three rounds, {@creature Luzgrigaul|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) emerges from the ocean. They sneak into the town and devour the brains of the unconscious. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 15 or higher notice Luzgrigaul. Otherwise, characters only the horrifying, brainless corpses left behind by their attack. If the characters attack Luzgrigaul the mind flayer doesn't stay to fight against the odds. They telepathically command the sahuagin to intervene, giving them a chance to escape.

entries.name: Flamsterd
entries: In the southwest of the Moonshae Isles is a small, barren island named Flamsterd. The island is barely inhabited, with only a few fishing communities on the eastern coast of the island where grass still grows. Further inland, and on the western coast, the island is a bleak wasteland. No plant save tough brown grass grows in the sandy soil, and few animals frequent the land save for colonies of seabirds which enjoy the lack of human disturbance.

entries.name: Flamsterd's Sunken Tower
entries: To the southwest of Flamsterd is a tower sunken beneath the waves. Characters are unlikely to notice the tower unless they travel past it underwater, or visit the southwest coast of Flamsterd. The tower is squat, with a crenelated top, and is surrounded by a lush garden. The structure and its surroundings are encased in a bubble of breathable air which allows everything other than seawater to pass through it. Because of this there are often helpless marine animals, mostly small fish, flopping around within the bubble having accidentally passed through the barrier.

The tower is occupied by Flamsterd (CG male Tethyrian human {@creature archmage}) and his three underlings nicknamed Eyh, Bie and See (LG humans {@creature apprentice wizard|vgm|apprentice wizards} of mixed race and gender).

Flamsterd is an ancient wizard after whom the island of Flamsterd was named. He left the island almost two centuries ago after his previous apprentices became unruly. Flemsterd practices the dangerous art of creating permanent spell effects. He has mastered permanent versions of the {@spell alter self}, {@spell darkvision}, and {@spell jump} spells. He is practising a permanent {@spell tongues} spell by on nearby whales, some of whom speak broken {@language Common}.

Characters who visit the mage can have permanent spells cast on themselves for 250 gp. If the characters are willing to be Flamsterd's experiment, he attempts to cast the permanent {@spell tongues} spell on them for free. Roll a {@dice d20}:

items: On a roll of 11 or higher the spell is successful.
On a roll of 10 or less the spell fails; roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|phb} table in chapter 3 of the {@i Player's Handbook} to see what effect occurs instead.

entries: Permanent spell effects put a character under the effect of said spell until ended by the {@spell dispel magic} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher who stay at the tower for more than an hour notice a clawing sound coming from within, broken every now and then by a screech. The sound is muffled but seems to come from the higher chambers of the tower. If confronted, Flamsterd maintains that it must be coming from the surrounding ocean. A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check reveals that he is lying.

If characters press the issue, Flamsterd takes the characters to a cramped chamber at the top of his tower. Within is a hideous, one-eyed creature that frantically skitters around the room through piles of discarded books and papers. Flamsterd explains that the creature is a {@creature nothic}, but used to be his apprentice Dea. Flamsterd doesn't know what caused the transformation but thinks Dea must have encountered dark magic that warped her form and mind. Dea is obsessed with magic items and pays particular attention to characters that display them.

If the characters give Dea a magic item she reveals that she was warped while attempting a {@spell scrying} spell on the city of Ascarle. She saw a creature there so alien that it terrified her. Before she could end the spell, the creature sent a pulse of psychic energy through the connection, transforming her into a nothic. Flamsterd does not tolerate violence toward Dea as he is sure she can be cured.

entries.name: Forest of Tethir
entries: This enormous forest, also known as Wealdath, is home to a large community of  ood elves and is considered the southern border of Amn. It stretches all the way to the end of the Dragon's Head peninsula and just as far east into the continent. The forest is not particularly thick, save at its heart where the evergreens become more densely packed. The Trade Way passes through the wood near the coast.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Twenty {@creature bugbear|mm|bugbears}, six {@creature centaur|mm|centaurs}, and a {@creature bugbear chief|mm} (with 100 hit points) are felling trees near the coastline. The bugbears are forcing the centaurs into labour, felling the trees and strapping the huge stands of timber to the creatures to be dragged to a sawing station. The planks are then stored on a ship called Grankhul's Shadow.

Unless characters intervene, the goblinoids fill the ship with timber in six hours. During this time, characters who can understand {@language Goblin} hear the bugbears discussing the high price of timber in the Nelanther Isles, the constant recruitment of new crew by the pirate captains, and rumours of a new Sea King in the western atolls. Characters also have the chance to sneak aboard Grankhul's Shadow, which is unoccupied while the bugbears work. Once the ship is filled, the bugbears kill the centaurs and leave, sailing west.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who sneak aboard Grankhul's Shadow unnoticed can steal from the vessel, as can those who defeat the goblinoids. The ship contains 2,500 cp, 140 sp and 30 gp in assorted coins, gems, and treasures. Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check also discover three magic items; roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what they find.

entries.name: Fort Morninglord
entries: This abandoned fortress is entirely bricked up. The place is regularly patrolled by a detachment of paladins from Elturguard, headed by the High Overseers of {@deity Torm|Faerûnian|scag} (eight LG Tethyrian human {@creature war priest|vgm|war priests} of Torm). If they catch characters snooping around, they explain that the entire garrison of paladins stationed at the fort disappeared a few years ago, hence the place was sealed shut. None should enter, lest they meet the same fate.
This might seem like a great adventure hook to some groups but plays no part in the storyline of this campaign. Any further adventure in Fort Morninglord is undertaken at the DM's discretion.

entries.name: Fort Vuuxaria
entries: The only permanent triton stronghold in the Trackless Sea is Fort Vuuxaria. This stone citadel is built in a deep-sea trench north of Gundarlun and Purple Rocks. Most tritons in this adventure hail from Vuuxaria, which was founded around a century ago. Vuuxaria stands on a rocky plateau within the sea trench and is built of hexagonal blocks of translucent polished green stone. The fort is equipped with siege weapons which protrude from domed towers punctuating the city's periphery, and is lit by hundreds of glass globes which contain bioluminescent jellyfish. Characters visiting the fort must deal with water pressure (see "{@hazard Water Pressure|CallfromtheDeep}" sidebar).

The tritons of Vuuxaria are not unwelcoming but have a poor understanding of the surface world, and assume that any visitors are here to thank them for their unending war against the horrors of the deep. Tritons have been waging war against elemental evils and marine monsters since their genesis and believe they are owed honour and prestige for their deeds. Triton society is highly militaristic, and there are only a few among the population who are not attached to the military in some fashion. Most of these are nobles visiting the Material Plane for a change of scene.

Fort Vuuxia's Stratigos, Feloren Vuuxariath (LG female triton {@creature champion|vgm}), manages the militia of Vuuxaria and is a master tactician. She commands ten Taxiarhos ({@creature gladiator|mm|gladiators}) who lead battalions of ten triton hoplites ({@creature veteran|mm|veterans}).

The tritons are aware of the existence of Slarkrethel, though they are yet to learn of Zellix'Phor. If the characters describe the actions of the Kraken Society and can provide evidence of the link between the society and Slarkrethel, Stratigos Feloren agrees to mobilise troops to attack the kraken. Six of the ten battalions are out hunting sahuagin, who have been plaguing the fort of late, and Feloren cannot defend the city with fewer than three battalions, so she sends for Taxiarhos Molos and the Dragon Turtle Battalion under he commands.

Each Taxiarhos from Fort Vuuxaria rides a {@creature hippocamp|CallfromtheDeep}; a blue-green creature native to the Elemental Plane of Water with a horse's body and a fish's tail. Hippocamps have the statistics of a {@creature warhorse} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: A hippocamp has a speed of 5 feet, and a swim speed of 60 feet.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: The hippocamp can breathe air and water.

Characters can be trained to ride a hippocamp mount for 250 gp which involves three days of intense training. Characters can buy a hippocamp for 400 gp. They can also buy hippocamp {@item barding|phb} and {@item lance|phb|lances}. The hippocamps are guarded day and night by eight triton {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} who work in shifts to ensure their safety from sahuagin attacks. The triton responsible for the care of the hippocamps is Hipparchus Zunis Pumanath (NG male triton {@creature gladiator}). Unlike the other tritons, Zunis was born on the Elemental Plane of Water in Fort Pumana. Zunis has come to detest the cold waters of the Material Plane and laments the lack of wild hippocamps here. A character can convince Zunis that they care for the beasts with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. If they do, he takes them to one side and says if they pay him 200 gp he'll arrange it so the changing of the guard is delayed later that day, giving them a chance to steal one of the hippocamps.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters staying at Fort Vuuxaria notice the fort is home to a race of fish-like humanoids with glassy eyes and purple skin. If the characters ask the tritons about them, they are told about the kuo-toa; insane creatures who paddle around the streets aimlessly. Normally the kuo-toa are seen as inconsequential, but recently they've been stealing things. If the characters ask around the noble houses, the tritons claim the kuo-toa take anything valuable if given the chance, but prefer idols and statuettes.

The {@creature kuo-toa} travel in groups of {@dice 2d4 + 2}. There is a {@chance 50} chance that any group has {@dice 1d4} stolen objects with them (roll on the {@table 25 gp Art Objects} table in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what the items are).

Characters can spy on the kuo-toa if they succeed on a DC 14 group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check. If the characters fail the kuo-toa notice them, and head back to their lair, luring the characters after them. The kuo-toa spend a few hours each day searching the city for interesting objects. Once the groups have collected three or four items they leave the city through a narrow crack in the plateau upon which it is built that cuts straight down into the rock. After following the tunnel for a hundred feet or more, it opens out into the lair of a {@creature morkoth|vgm} who refers to itself in the third person as Tentacular Spectacular.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Vuuxaria (Player).png}.}

entries.name: M1. Kuo-Toa Caverns
entries: If the characters follow the kuo-toa, read or paraphrase the following:

The winding tunnels lead to a narrow passageway which ends in a hole. Beanth this is a drop down into an air-filled cavern. There doesn't seem to be a material barrier keeping the water from rushing down into the cavern.
If the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:

You hop down into the dry cavern. Above you, the surface of the water holds firm like a membrane. The dank caverns and tunnels around you are covered with a thin, slimy fluid, and have piles of rags peppered with fishbones in the corners.

entries.name: Entrance & Dimensions
entries: The entrance to the caverns lies just under 10 feet up. Creatures attempting to leave through the hole must succeed on a DC 12 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. The caverns vary from 4 to 6 feet tall.

entries.name: Slime
entries: The floor in this area is covered in slime. When a creature with feet (other than kuo-toa) moves for the first time on its turn, it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Athletics}) check or fall {@condition prone}. A creature can avoid making the check by treating the area as difficult terrain.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Scurrying through the caverns are four {@creature kuo-toa}, plus any that entered with the characters. If the kuo-toa know the characters are there, they flee to {@area m2|fvm2}. If more than half of them are killed, they try to escape the dungeon through {@area m5|fvm5} via the secret tunnel.

entries.name: Net Traps
entries: Each natural stair is trapped with a {@trap falling net} trap (see chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). Creatures caught in the nets are grabbed by the kuo-toa and taken to {@area m4|fvm4} to be imprisoned. One of the kuo-toa goes to {@area m2|fvm2} to get the keys.

entries.name: Water Bubble
entries: The lowest chamber contains a bubble of water which fills the chamber and surrounding tunnels.

entries.name: Secret Tunnel
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice chisel lines around a section of wall. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check allows a character to open the door. The tunnel beyond smells of burning. Creatures here move at twice their normal speed (the tunnel is 85 feet long).

The cavernous chamber ahead is filled with an enormous bubble of water. It is lit by a slowly pulsing mass of pearlescent matter floating inside the bubble. Huge white crystals thrust out from the eastern wall and floor, glittering in the twinkling light. The walls of the cave contain hundreds of alcoves, ranging in size from a few inches across to a few feet. Filling these alcoves are an abundance of treasures.

entries.name: Cavern Dimensions
entries: The water bubble is 50 feet tall. The ceiling is 30 feet above that. There are two rocky shelves at a height of 60 feet. Climbing up to the shelves requires a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The {@creature morkoth|vgm} Tentacular Spectacular swims in the water bubble. The morkoth is evil and delights in imprisoning the creatures, who it considers living treasures. Tentacular attempts to charm the characters, knocking them {@condition unconscious} in combat as a last resort.
Tentacular is a stuttering creature prone to excitement who repeatedly touches its treasures with its tentacles.

Characters who ask the morkoth to stop stealing from Vuuxaria offend Tentacular. It has been here far longer than the triton fort and thinks the 'blue-skins' are repulsive. If asked about the {@item survival mantle|vgm} in {@area m3|fvm3}, Tentacular explains that it is an illithid breathing machine. Tentacular describes illihtids as 'inferior, brain-eating tentacle-faces'.

entries.name: Crystals
entries: There are nine large crystals in the chamber. Each has an AC of 13 and 10 hit points. Casting a spell within 20 feet of a crystal causes a wild magic surge (roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|phb} table in chapter 3 of the {@i Player's Handbook}), centred on the caster.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The alcoves in the walls are mostly worthless trinkets (roll on the {@item Trinket|phb} table in chapter 5 of the {@i Player's Handbook}). Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence check, or spend 10 minutes searching, discover items worth a total of 3,500 gp. They also discover a {@item wand of stone shape|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}), a {@item ring of warmth}, a {@item wand of web}, a {@item wand of diminution|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}), a {@item quaal's feather token, anchor|dmg|Quaal's feather token: anchor}, a githyanki {@item silver sword|mtf|silver greatsword} (belonging to Fenelzi'ir; see {@area m4|fvm4}), a {@item potion of greater healing}, a {@item potion of vitality}, and the keys to the cells in {@area m4|fvm4}.

This chamber of smoothed worked stone seems out of place in the cavernous dungeon, not least because it is perpetually snowing here. In the centre of the chamber are two stone statues of tritons wielding spears and shields. The western and southern walls are marked by archways, behind which are nooks lit by flickering purple flames.

entries.name: Light
entries: The nooks are lit by purple {@spell continual flame} spells.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Resting in each nook is a valuable item. Going anticlockwise, they contain a {@item wind fan}, a {@item survival mantle|vgm}, a masterpiece painting of Vuuxaria (worth 2,500 gp), a {@item staff of the eel|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}), and a small clock powered by flowing water filled with dozens of tiny cogs (1,500 gp).

entries.name: Traps
entries: Each nook is trapped. A creature that enters an alcove without telepathically asking it to remain open triggers a magical ward. The ward can be noticed with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. It can be destroyed with a {@spell dispel magic} spell (DC 20).

If the trap is triggered the stone archway melts, sealing the doorway. The nook is then filled with the {@spell cloudkill} spell for 1 minute. Smashing open the sealed archway requires a successful DC 20 Strength check. The archways have AC 17, 20 hit points, and resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

Standing on the ceiling, encased in a cage of rusted iron, is a humanoid figure. The entire room seems to be turned on its head. The walls are formed of an oozing, greasy material that flows up toward the ceiling. The oozing floor swirls endlessly.

entries.name: Gravity
entries: This chamber is under the effects of a permanent {@spell reverse gravity} spell. Characters can climb onto the ceiling with a successful DC 15 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check.

entries.name: Cages
entries: Four locked cages protrude from the ceiling. They can be opened with a successful DC 20 Strength check, or a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. The keys are in an alcove in {@area m2|fvm2}. The cages are covered with glyphs which radiate an {@spell antimagic field}, preventing creatures inside from using magic. Two of the cells are empty, the others contain:

items: Felenzi'ir (LE female {@creature githyanki knight}) who begs to be freed in {@language Gith|mm}. She has been Tentacular's captive for six years, giving her irrepressible jitters which pose disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws that involve Strength or Dexterity. The jitters can be suppressed with the {@spell calm emotions} spell or cured with a {@spell greater restoration} spell. Felenzi'ir makes little sense unless reunited with her {@item silver sword|mtf|silver greatsword} (see {@area m2|fvm2}). If characters cure her madess, she takes the characters to a githyanki crèche in Flame Fault (see the "{@area Tuern|tuern|x}" section).

Kholos Vuuxariath (LG male triton {@creature martial arts adept|vgm|martial arts expert}) who remains stoic despite the chaos surrounding him. Kholos was an avid explorer of the Sword Coast but was captured by Tentacular Spectacular to tell stories of this other land. If characters free Kholos he can help pull strings for them in Fort Vuuxariath, as he once ran the monastery there. Kholos is cheery despite his imprisonment, and has a serious taste for cheese, which he calls 'solid milk'.

entries: Light from a chamber to the north is reflected hundreds of times by the mirrored walls of this cavern. Immense crystals sprout from the north wall, piercing the layer of shiny metal. Reflections in the warped mirrors are horrifyingly distorted.

entries.name: Water Bubble
entries: The water bubble is 10 feet tall. The ceiling is 10 feet above that.

entries.name: Mirrored Walls & Ceiling
entries: The cavern is covered with reflective metal. A creature that is not submerged in water that sees their reflection must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or fall under the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. A creature can avoid this by remaining submerged, or averting their eyes, leaving them {@condition blinded}.

entries.name: Crystals
entries: There are nine large crystals in the chamber. Each has an AC of 13 and 10 hit points. Casting a spell within 20 feet of a crystal causes a wild magic surge (roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|phb} table in chapter 3 of the {@i Player's Handbook}), centred on the caster.

entries.name: Southern Tunnel
entries: This 100-foot tunnel leads to an exit.

entries.name: Secret Tunnel
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice chisel lines around a section of wall. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check allows a character to open the door. The tunnel beyond smells of burning. Creatures here move at twice their normal speed (the tunnel is 85 feet long).

entries.name: Gauntlgrym
entries: Once a great city and bastion of the empire of Delzoun, this dwarven stronghold stood abandoned for centuries beneath the mountains. Recently an army of dwarves led by Bruenor Battlehammer reclaimed it, ousting drow squatters and sending them scurrying back into the Underdark. Bruenor now sits on Gauntlgrym's throne as king.

The "heart" of Gauntlgrym is its legendary forge, within which is trapped a fire primordial known as {@creature Maegera the Dawn Titan|skt}. For more information on Gauntlgrym and its inhabitants, see the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag|2|Gauntlgrym} and the adventure {@adventure Out of the Abyss|oota}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: While the characters are visiting the dwarven citadel, a {@creature mindwitness|vgm} and six {@creature drow elite warrior} thralls attack the workforce and run rampant throughout the upper levels near the forge. Lurking nearby but out of sight is {@creature Druskis|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). While the drow and mindwitness cause havoc on the streets of Gauntlgrym, the mind flayer gorges on as many dwarves as possible, hoping to gain important information about the fall of the mind flayer colony which used to reside beneath Gauntlgrym, and create new mind flayers from the dwarves.

The characters encounter the mindwitness and thralls at the top of a 60-foot-long, 40-foot-wide, 100-foot-tall hallway crisscrossed by raised walkways which connect different areas of the city. A dozen dwarf {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} are fleeing from the thralls when characters arrive, but they run straight into the path of the mindwitness. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 11 or higher notice Druskis devouring the brain of a dwarven soldier in the shadows of an archway on the hall floor. Druskis leaves on initiative 20 the following round.

entries.name: Goldenfields
entries: Goldenfields is a huge, walled temple-farm dedicated to {@deity Chauntea|Faerûnian|scag}, the goddess of agriculture. Called "the Granary of the North," it is the only reason many Northerners ever taste soft-fleshed fruit larger than bush berries. Waterdeep and its neighbours consume the temple's reliable output: carefully husbanded grains and dried, oil-packed, or salted foodstuffs preserved in vast storage cellars, vats, and squat stone grain-towers.

Run by Abbot Ellardin Darovik (NG male Damaran human {@creature priest} of Chauntea), Goldenfields is a stronghold of the Emerald Enclave. Members of that faction are as welcome here as clergy of Chauntea; many of them stay for months at a time to help with the work and the vigilant defence of the farm against insects and blights, as well as would-be vandals and plunderers. Hired guards and adventurers patrol the walls and the land immediately around them. Inside the farm, young treants allied with the Emerald Enclave hide within stands of trees, ready to animate them to repel invaders. More than five thousand people live and work in Goldenfields year-round, farming more than twenty square miles of tillage in gangs of hardworking gardeners.

entries.name: Gull Rocks
entries: Half a dozen islets jut up from the Sea of Swords to the west of the Moonshae Isles. This string of tiny islands is called Gull Rocks and is home to a colony of aarakocra who are expert fisherfolk and navigators. The aarakocra of Gull Rocks are almost exclusively white with black wings and yellow beaks. Their wingspans are far larger than their mainland kin, and their beaks resemble those of seagulls. The aarakocra colony is led by five aarakocra {@creature priest|mm|priests} who summon an {@creature air elemental} if the islets are threatened. {@note (You may find {@creature aarakocra priest|CallfromtheDeep|these statistics} useful.)}

entries.name: Gundarlun
entries: The island nation of Gundarlun is a string of barren mountains rising up from the Trackless Sea. Mighty waves crash against its rocky shores throughout the year. Clinging to the mountainsides above the water are stone keeps with fishing villages huddled around them, each one ruled by a ruthless jarl who answers to the King of Gundarlun, {@creature King Olgrave Redaxe|CallfromtheDeep|Olgrave Redaxe} (CN male Illuskan human {@creature berserker} with 90 hit points). The king lives in a crumbling fortress that overlooks Gundbarg, the island's only port.
A full description of Gundarlun and the locations on the island can be found in {@adventure chapter 1|CallfromtheDeep|2|Gundarlun}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: When characters visit Gundbarg, they discover the town is under attack by a slime-covered worm of immense size with barbed tentacles that lash out from the creature's mouth. The worm is a {@creature neothelid|vgm}; the result of a mind flayer tadpole from the crash site devouring its kin and rapidly mutating. Now mature, the neothelid has become hungry for humanoid brains, with the nearest source being Gundbarg.

When the characters arrive on the scene the neothelid is smashing apart one of the dragon ships of the Kingsfleet filled with injured warriors hoping for a few days respite. The warriors are of little help against the aberration, save as a temporary distraction. On its first turn, the neothelid uses acid breath on the fleeing crew, causing half a dozen of them to melt away, leaving only their brains behind. After this, the neothelid attacks a random character each turn.

After two rounds of combat with the neothelid {@creature Tharcereli|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) appears on the docks and starts attacking the creature. Mind flayers view neothelids as abominations that must be exterminated. If Tharcereli drops below half its hit points it flees through the streets of Gunbarg, heading west toward Berranzo. The mind flayer does not stop until it reaches the mines, where it meets with Thiliossk before returning to Ascarle. See "{@adventure Berranzo|CallfromtheDeep|2|Berranzo}" in chapter 1 for more information.
If the characters meet with King Redaxe after the attack, he rewards them with a {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|dragonship} of their own and a crew of forty {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}.

entries.name: Gwynneth
entries: Over the past century the isle of Gwynneth has become ever more fey and mysterious. It is home to the elven realm of Sarifal, under the rule of High Lady Ordalf. Sarifal shares the island with the reclusive mountain kingdom of Synnoria, home of the Llewyr elves, plus a few small shield dwarf settlements and the ruins of Caer Corwell, the former Ffolk settlement on Gwynneth. High King Derid wants to reclaim the old citadel and rebuild it as an embassy but has yet to secure Lady Ordalf's consent to do so. Gwynneth is also home to Myrloch Vale, a lush valley nestled in the mountains with the shimmering waters of the Myrloch to the south. Druid circles are active in the Vale, allied with the elves and the fey creatures of this area.

In the north of the island High Lady Ordalf's son, Prince Araithe, leads the struggle against the dark fey of the forest of Winterglen. The prince is a pragmatist willing to accept aid in fending off his people's foes, and is known to allow adventuring companies to cross the Strait of Alaron and land on Gwynneth if they pledge to aid the cause.

If the characters need a guide to the Moonshae Isles they can get in contact with Eliri Mystralath (CG female half-elf {@creature druid} who can change into a {@creature brown bear}), a wild-eyed, redhaired maniac of a woman who knows the islands like the back of her hand. Eliri is part Llewyr and part Ffolk and is a proud member of the oldest druidic circle on Gwynneth. She insists on painting the faces of her allies with blue paint for luck. Eliri knows the location of several Moonwells which the characters can use and has had vague visions of the Black Armada while bathing in these pools. The exact information contained within Eliri's visions is up to the DM.
Characters might end up in Gywnneth if they accept {@area Hamma the Dryad's Quest|bgqhtdq|x} in chapter 2.

entries.name: Helm's Hold
entries: Located a short distance southeast of Neverwinter, Helm's Hold is a fortified monastery enclosed on all sides by stone walls patrolled by members of the Order of the Gilded Eye, a splinter sect of the Order of the Gauntlet. Helm's Hold is firmly under the Gilded Eye's control and its members have taken {@deity Helm|Faerûnian|scag|Helm's} doctrine of protection to extremes. The high-minded inquisitors of the Gilded Eye are convinced that evil is rampant. They are determined to root out those under "demonic influence" and are quick to persecute anyone who doesn't act in accordance with their beliefs.

Within the walls of Helm's Hold are numerous residences surrounding a central district called the Heartward, wherein characters can find a roomy tavern called the Old Dirty Dwarf, several quiet hostels, and a bustling marketplace. A wooden hangman's scaffold stands in the centre of the marketplace and on certain nights, when clouds obscure the waning moon, luminous ghosts wander around it, going about the business of the living. Phantom vendors sell ephemeral apples at empty stands, ghost children play in the streets, and spirits hang one another on the scaffold. Some of the scenes appear to be re-enactments of past events, whereas others have not yet occurred. The ghosts speak mostly nonsense, but some of what they say might offer clues to past or future happenings.

Dominating the skyline is the Cathedral of {@deity Helm|Faerûnian|scag}, an inspiring edifice of pale grey stone that is visible for miles around. As much a fortress as a temple, the cathedral contains an orphanage, hospital, asylum, and training grounds for Gilded Eye initiates. Holy Watcher Qerria (LG female Tethyrian human {@creature priest} of Helm), who presides over the cathedral, is determined to root out corruption wherever she finds it. Few doubt that her words carry the weight of divine wisdom. She is served by dozens of Gilded Eye inquisitors (male and female {@creature cult fanatic|mm|cult fanatics} of various alignments and ethnicities) who employ a host of {@creature acolyte|mm|acolytes}, {@creature assassin|mm|assassins}, {@creature guard|mm|guards}, {@creature knight|mm|knights}, {@creature spy|mm|spies}, and {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}. Evildoers and enemies of the Gilded Eye are brought to Helm's Hold to face judgment here. Those deemed to be under "demonic influence" or who threaten the Gilded Eye are hanged, their bodies burned to ashes to prevent them from being raised.

entries.name: High Forest
entries: Although much less expansive than in ancient times, the High Forest is still vast and mysterious. The place is home to {@creature treant|mm|treants} of enormous size, {@creature giant elk|mm|stags with antlers as wide as a wagon}, brown bears bigger than large sheds, {@creature owlbear|mm|owlbears}, {@creature wolf|mm|wolves}, {@creature unicorn|mm|unicorns}, and many other creatures, including fiercely territorial wood elves and Uthgardt barbarians of the Tree Ghost tribe. The forest holds hidden settlements, haunted ruins, fey crossings, and ancient magical wards. In the outermost fringes of the forest, woodcutters ply their trade, and outlaws on the run might find refuge. But as everyone knows, those who venture too deep into the High Forest are often not seen again.

entries.name: High Moor
entries: A great cataclysm occurred on the High Moor long ago, wiping out an entire elven kingdom, but little evidence of this event now remains except for some haunted ruins, tombs, and dungeons shrouded in thick fog. Many adventurers have perished in search of these ancient sites, for the High Moor is home to deadly monsters.

entries.name: High Road
entries: This well-traveled highway follows the coast from Luskan to Waterdeep, connecting with Neverwinter along the way. For years the stretch of road between Neverwinter and Waterdeep fell into disuse and disrepair because of frequent monster attacks. When he was both Lord Protector of Neverwinter and Open Lord of Waterdeep, Dagult Neverember hired adventurers to make the old road safe and spent considerable coin to repair it. Many now consider the High Road a safer means of travel than a sea voyage thanks to pirate attacks.

entries.name: Hundelstone
entries: At the highest elevations along Ten Trail only a few shrubs cling to life amid patches of moss-covered rock. Travellers on this route eventually reach Hundelstone, perching on the mountain slopes much like the surrounding flora. The town's buildings are low, with most of their rooms cut from the hard soil and rock below ground level, and their roofs steeply pitched to better shed the snows that blankets the mountains in the winter. The shield dwarves and rock gnomes of Hundelstone get a chuckle out of warning visitors to stoop low as they walk about town, lest they be blown away by the wind.

For most folk, Hundelstone is either the last outpost of civilisation before taking the pass to Icewind Dale, or the first welcome sign of refuge after making the wearying trip back. Many of the dwarves and gnomes here spend their days excavating tunnels, mining ore, or smelting and smithing the local iron and tin. (Adventurers who venture into these tunnels might be surprised to find that some descend for miles, even to the Underdark.) Hundelstone's few score human residents are mostly sellswords who earn a living as caravan guards or beast hunters in the crags.

entries.name: Ice Peak
entries: The frozen island that lies southeast of the Sea of Moving Ice is named for the snow-capped promontory that dominates its northern half. Most of the inhabitants live in a few settlements clustered around the twin bays on the southern shore. Caves in the mountain's peak serve as a lair for Arveiaturace, the white wyrm known to sailors as Iceclaws thanks to her habit of diving on hapless vessels and tearing them apart with her talons.

Longships crowd the docks of Aurilssbarg, the island's largest community. Typical of the settlements on Ice Peak, the streets of Aurilssbarg are paved with logs laid side by side, and its buildings are low wooden structures whose pitched roofs are covered in sod. The heart of Aurilssbarg is Green Hall, a spacious tavern with a lengthy firepit that can spit six goats at a time to feed the hungry crews that arrive after unloading their ships at the docks. Locals come here too to hear the latest news from the mainland, although by the time it reaches Ice Peak such news is often out of date and wildly exaggerated, little better than idle rumour. Still, the isolated inhabitants of Aurilssbarg eat it up all the same.

The island's smaller coastal settlements include the fishing and trapping villages of Bjorn's Hold and Icewolf. The natives of Ice Peak survive by catching fish and hunting goats, seals, and whales. The island boasts a large yeti population who feed on mountain goats, avoiding Northlanders unless food is scarce.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
