entries: Arriving with the characters to Ice Peak is a Zhentarim coaster crewed by twelve Black Network {@creature thug|mm|thugs} from Leilon with a hold full of crates. The ship is captained by the audacious {@creature Perra Myastan|CallfromtheDeep} (NE female black dragonborn {@creature swashbuckler|vgm}) who rolls up at the Green Hall with half a dozen kegs of strong ale. Perra puts on a show of the strength of the Zhentarim during this time of piracy, encouraging any who want work to join a vessel that's faster and smarter than the pirates with the Black Network. The bravado is accentuated by Perra's pet {@creature flying snake} which swoops around the room, landing on those who seem tempted for a moment before moving on. Characters who succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check realise the captain is causing a distraction. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice a pair of dwarven Zhentarim {@creature thug|mm|thugs} sneaking in the back of the Green Hall with a keg that seems to be shaking unnaturally.

The keg contains a {@creature swarm of cranium rats|vgm} which the Zhents have been paid to smuggle into the Green Hall. Here, the rats can spy on some of the best-travelled crews of the North and gather information on trade routes to target. The information is collected by Zellix'Phor who passes it on to Sea King Tentrix.

Characters who reveal the truth about Captain Myastan provoke her ire, and she challenges them to a duel. Refusing the duel reflects badly on the characters in the eyes of the sailors, leaving them unable to recruit crew members here, or join the crew of another vessel. If the characters accept, they must nominate one character to duel with Perra. The duel is one-on-one melee combat in which magic is forbidden, though this doesn't stop Perra using her breath weapon to open the brawl. If the characters defeat Perra, they have the right to commandeer her ship, Le Dragon Noir, though the Zhentarim might try to retrieve it at some point. If Perra defeats the character, she has the right to commandeer the characters' ship.

entries.name: Icewind Dale
entries: Icewind Dale has snow, ice, and freezing temperatures in abundance. The sun never rises far above the horizon even at the height of summer, which is a fleeting thing. Winter here is long and ruthless.

Icewind Dale is surrounded by perilous terrain. The ice cliffs of the Reghed Glacier rise up in the east like prison walls. The towering, snow-capped peaks of the Spine of the World loom to the south. To the north and west, the Sea of Moving Ice churns bergs and floes in an endless tumult, like winter grinding its teeth in anticipation of its next freezing assault. Between these formidable obstacles lies windswept tundra dotted with settlements and the occasional small forest or stand of trees.

A singular mountain called Kelvin's Cairn rises from the heart of Icewind Dale. During summer, snow from Kelvin's Cairn flows into three mineral-rich lakes: Maer Dualdon, Lac Dinneshere, and Redwaters. By midsummer, Icewind Dale shakes off the torpor of winter and comes forth in full flower. Grasses grow two or three feet high in the span of weeks. Birds flock to the marshes formed by the thawing soil, and reindeer calves fill out the diminished herds.

Reghed barbarians follow the reindeer herds as they migrate across Icewind Dale, and dwarf miners haunt the caves and tunnels beneath Kelvin's Cairn, rarely emerging except to trade ore for food. Most of lcewind Dale's inhabitants live in ten permanent settlements collectively known as Ten-Towns:

items: The walled town of Bryn Shander, which lies at the northern end of the Ten Trail, is the first stop for most visiting merchants and traders and is by far the largest of the ten communities.

The hunting and fishing villages of Bremen, Targos, Termalaine, and Lonelywood line the shores of Maer Dualdon, which feeds into the Shaengarne River and holds seemingly countless numbers of knucklehead trout.
The villages of Dougan's Hole and Good Mead stand a few miles apart on the north shore of Redwaters which, contrary to its name, sparkles emerald green during the day and silver at night.
The town of Easthaven and, nestled among the foothills of Kelvin's Cairn, the villages of CaerDineval and Caer-Konig hug the shores of Lac Dinneshere, which freezes in winter.

entries: The population of Ten-Towns is composed mostly of humans and dwarves, with the humans outnumbering the dwarves roughly twenty to one. In times of great peril, the leaders of Ten-Towns, known as Town Speakers, meet at Bryn Shander to discuss solutions to their problems. If one of the smaller settlements comes under attack by a threat too great to overcome, its inhabitants are trained to flee to Bryn Shander and take shelter behind its walls.

Characters travelling through Icewind Dale are likely to encounter creatures such as {@creature frost giant|mm|frost giants}, {@creature yeti}, and {@creature remorhaz|mm|remorhazes}. If the characters are near to the coast, they are almost certain to encounter one of the giant greatships, crewed by sixteen frost giants, that raid the towns and villages from time to time. Characters who spy on these ships, or who manage to charm or capture a frost giant, hear talk of Sea King Tentrix; a pirate lord who is taking the coast by storm. He hails from the south but has even managed to recruit some frost giants to his cause.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Each of the Ten Towns settlements has wanted posters up bearing a charcoal sketch of a human with dark eyes, a thick beard, and a missing ear. The posters read "The Town Speakers offer a bounty of 500 gp to whomever can deliver to them the pirate captain of the Howling Fiend. Wanted dead or alive".

If characters visit Lac Dinneshere they are greeted by the sight of two flaming fishing vessels. Circling around behind the burning boats is a coaster called the Howling Fiend. There are numerous {@item rowboat|CallfromtheDeep|rowboats} and the odd {@item keelboat|CallfromtheDeep} or coaster moored on the shores of Lac Dinneshere that the party could commandeer to catch the pirates.

The Howling Fiend is equipped with a {@object black ice ram|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) and is crewed by twelve {@creature thug|mm|thugs}. Their captain, {@creature Pyrse Auliff|CallfromtheDeep} (CN male Illuskan human {@creature swashbuckler|vgm} with a {@item +1 black ice rapier|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep})) is a member of Ship Rethnor of Luskan but is under the influence of {@creature Vaelish Gant|CallfromtheDeep}, a {@creature mage} (without 4th- or 5th-level spells). The crew of the Howling Fiend fight to the death and are clearly insane. This is due to their constant proximity to black ice. Captain Pyrse offers to trade information for his life or freedom, namely that he's working for Vaelish, who can be found in Bryn Shander.

If characters pursue the lead, they easily catch up with Gant, who has no idea that he's been revealed. Gant is a member of the Arcane Brotherhood working for Jendrick the Blue (see the "{@area Luskan|luskan|x}" section for more information).

entries.name: Ioma
entries: One of the larger islands in the Nelanther, Ioma is a popular port for crews travelling through. Although still riddled with pirates, Ioma, and its largest settlement Ioma Town, is relatively peaceful compared to the other isles thanks to the presence of The Triarchy; three Cowled Wizards from Amn who oversee the mining operations on the island. The low mountain of Ioma is marked by a vein of purple quartz, dubbed Iomic crystal, that was once thought to have magicreflecting powers but is now sold as faux amethyst.

The Triarchy is made of three {@creature mage|mm|mages}; Jessiri Evermantle (N female Tethyrian human) who hails from Amn and is the unofficial head of the group, Marcon Ramfosco (NG male Turami human) who deals primarily with providing protection for the miners from the dangers of the island, and Caran Greywyrm (LN female Chondathan human) who takes charge of the books for the Amnian government.

The majority of inhabitants of Ioma are civilised humanoids, but like anywhere in the Nelanthers, there are also lizardfolk, minotaur, orcs, and ogres who hold sway over various parcels of land and bodies of water. Tribes of the various races form and fold every few tendays causing constant skirmishes on land and battles at sea.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Although adventurous types pass through the Nelanthers daily, most are only interested in the opportunities piracy can present. A few hours after the characters arrive in Ioma Town they are approached by Marcon Ramfosco who asks a favour of them. The crystal miners have been struggling lately with a pair of harpies who seem intent on preventing them from doing their work. The monstrosities have been luring miners off the cliffs to their death with their songs and swooping down to attack them directly. Ramfosco promises a reward of 100 gp each for each harpy head. The next excursion to the mine is tomorrow morning.

If the characters choose not to accompany the miners (a group of twenty {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} of mixed race and gender) they can track down the harpy lair with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check and fight the two creatures in their lair. If they kill the harpies, the characters can recover {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} and discover a clutch of harpy eggs, presumably the cause of the harpies' aggression.

If the characters accompany the miners, they are attacked by the harpies while crossing a gorge on the mountainside. The gorge is half a mile long, 50 feet wide, and 100 feet deep but crossed in several places by sturdy rope bridges. Each bridge is 15 feet wide and can take the weight of several wagons filled with stone. While crossing, one of the lead miners slows their pace and looks into the distance searchingly. Suddenly, they run toward the edge of the bridge. Characters within 60 feet that succeed on a DC 20 Dexterity check can reach the miner in time to stop them plunging over the edge to their death. After this, the harpies arrive and use their songs to a devastating effect.

The harpies plaguing Ioma are more dangerous than most of their kin. They use the statistics of a {@creature ioman harpy|CallfromtheDeep|harpy} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: They have a Dexterity of 18 ({@d20 4}, AC 14).
They have 63 hit points.

Their claws deal 8 ({@damage 2d6 + 1}) slashing damage, and they wield {@item shortbow|phb|shortbows} instead of {@item club|phb|clubs}: {@hit 6} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target, dealing 7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage on a hit. They can make three claw attacks or two shortbow attacks.
The DC for their Luring Song is 15.
They have a challenge rating of 3 (700 XP).

items.name: Flyby
entries: The harpy doesn't provoke an {@action opportunity attack} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

entries.name: Ironmaster
entries: The dwarven city of Ironmaster is perched at the western edge of Icewind Dale, where the Shaengarne River flows into the Sea of Moving Ice. The city is nestled in a great cleft where the Shaengarne rushes to the sea. It's stone towers rise like spikes from the valley floor, and the rooms and passages of Ironmaster weave in and out of nevermelting ice and the stone of the valley walls. Mining tunnels extend from the valley walls far below the tundra, providing the dwarves with an apparently limitless supply of iron.

Ironmaster is populated exclusively by dwarves. Members of other races are forbidden to set foot in Ironmaster Vale. Great stone menhirs marked with the city's coat-of-arms, a red anvil on a grey diamond, are arranged in a perimeter around the vale to warn away travellers who stray too close.

Ironmaster is ruled by {@creature Lord Clanmaster Stogue Sstar|CallfromtheDeep} (LG male shield dwarf {@creature veteran} who wields a {@item battleaxe|phb} instead of a {@item longsword|phb}). Although Sstar is grateful for any help the characters can offer (see below), he is loathe to let them stay in the city. Instead, he rewards each character with 100 gp worth of gems for each giant they kill and asks that they respect the culture of the dwarves of Ironmaster and leave.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters who visit Ironmaster for the first time find the city in chaos. Four {@creature frost giant|mm|frost giants} from Svardborg have landed in a giant greatship and are scooping up the dwarves into huge lobster pots. The giants are split up, allowing characters to attack them one at a time. Although the dwarves of Ironmaster would not normally tolerate the presence of non-dwarves in the city, they need all the help they can get.

If two of the giants are slain, the remaining two make a break for their ship and flee back to Svardborg. If cornered, the giants fight to the death. If caught, they don't reveal anything about their motives. Characters who examine the bodies of the giants easily notice the huge kraken tattoos on their arms, indicating their loyalty the Kraken Society.

entries.name: Iumathiashae
entries: Buildings of water-sculpted rock, seaweed, shells, and glittering mother of pearl soar in harmonious spirals and curves up from the seafloor in the sea elf city of Iumathiashae. This truly magnificent underwater settlement is one of the first barriers between the Realms and Evermeet: a fabled, heavenly domain of the elves. Evermeet is protected by all manner of barriers and wards, one of which, the cyclone barrier, is maintained by the elves of Iumathiashae. The great city beneath the waves glows constantly with a green-yellow light that can be seen even from the surface of the ocean, though only the brave dare to swim down and take a look. Iumathiashae is patrolled at all hours by sea elf {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} riding {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} or giant scallop shell chariots pulled by {@creature hippocamp|CallfromtheDeep|hippocampi}. Unless characters are expected, the sea elves are likely to turn them away. Characters who are determined to meet with King Elashor, the leader of the community, must succeed on a DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check to be shown to his chambers.

King Elashor (CG male sea elf {@creature noble}) is a serenely calm ruler who lets his people keep to themselves. The community is one of farmers and fishers, and Elashor is happy to settle minor disputes while upkeeping his pearl garden. Despite his calm, Elashor knows he is responsible for deterring foolhardy folk from attempting the journey to Evermeet, which he doesn't take lightly. Every hour, sea elf {@creature mage|mm|mages} upkeep a permanent magical storm to the west of Iumathiashae, and patrols of chariot-riding soldiers can be seen coming and going from the city constantly. If characters get an audience with Elashor he welcomes them to stay for a short while. Any attempts to muster forces from him fail; the elves of Iumathiashae are of a different world to the mortals of Faerûn.

entries.name: Korinn Archipelago
entries: Hundreds of rocky islands form this archipelago north of the Moonshae Isles. Seafaring barbarians and marine monstrosities prowl the waters around these islands, which are home to griffons, harpies, wyverns, dragons, goblinoids, and old ruins haunted by evil wizards, gargoyles, and other forsaken creatures. The islands are populated mostly by Northlanders, who herd sheep, fish, and occasionally go raiding or pirating. Dozens of separate settlements form mini-kingdoms with little unifying them besides a shared Northlander culture.

There's no safe harbour for outsiders in the archipelago. For other Northls, the settlement of Westhaven on Pandira serves as a neutral ground where they might come to port, wait out a storm, or resupply. Those who accompanying a Northl to Westhaven might be permitted to stay for a while, but they certainly aren't afforded the same respect.
Characters might find themselves visiting Pandira on the Korinn Archipelago if they accept {@area Priestess of High Moonlight Melessa Suaril's Quest|wdqmsq|x} in chapter 2.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: When characters first arrive in the Korinn Archipelago, they are attacked by a marine chimera under the control Ungruk Shipsmasher (NE male {@creature orc blade of ilneval|vgm}). The orc is captain of a longship crewed by thirty Northlander {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} and ten half-orc {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}. The sail of the ship sports a bloody longsword: the symbol of {@deity Ilneval|Orc|vgm}.

The pirates wait nearby in the {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep} while the chimera wears the characters down. If Ungruk Shipsmasher is killed, the chimera breaks rank and attacks the closest creature. The {@creature marine chimera|CallfromtheDeep|chimera} has the hindquarters of a giant eel, the forequarters of an enormous turtle, and the leathery wings of a white dragon, along with the heads of those three creatures. It uses the statistics of a {@creature chimera} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: It has a base speed of 10 feet, and a swim speed of 30 feet.
It has a tail attack instead of horn attack which deals an additional {@damage 1d4} lightning damage on a hit.
Its claw attack deals 9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) slashing damage.
It has a Cold Breath instead of a Fire Breath, which deals cold damage instead of fire damage.

entries.name: Kressilacc
entries: In a deep-sea trench between Oman's Isle and Alaron in the Moonshaes is the sahuagin settlement of Kressilacc. Sea devils rarely settle permanently in one place thanks to their disinterest in building, but Kressilacc is an exception to that rule. Kressilacc is a ruined sea elf city that was won by the sahuagin in an underwater war that lasted almost a century between the sahuagin and the elves of Tír faoi Thoinn.

Kressilacc is currently ruled by a circle of five {@creature sahuagin priestess|mm|sahuagin priestesses} who venerate the shark god {@deity Sekolah|Nonhuman|phb}, and breed {@creature giant shark|mm|giant sharks} which they believe are his children. Life in Kressilacc is dangerous even for sahuagin. The daily ritual consists of numerous sacrifices by the priestesses and blood sports including giant crab wrestling, gladiatorial matches, and obstacle races to sort the weak from the strong, and to appease their bloodthirsty god.

In order for the characters to visit Kressilacc, they must conceal their identities or slip into the shadows of the ruined sea elf city. If they are seen by the sahuagin at any time, they are ruthlessly attacked or driven out of the city. Although there are no barons in Kressilacc, the priestesses are just as brutal and would accept the characters as a great sacrifice to Sekolah.

entries.name: Kryptgarden Forest
entries: A small wooded region near Westbridge hides many dwarven ruins and the extensive underground city known as Southkrypt. For centuries, Kryptgarden Forest has been the home and hunting ground of the ancient female green dragon, Claugiyliamatar, better known as Old Gnawbone. She earned her nickname from her habit of gnawing on old kills, and is often seen with a mangled corpse hanging from her mouth. Other dragons rarely remain in Kryptgarden Forest for long, because Claugiyliamatar drives them out.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Claugiyliamatar uses her collection of {@item crystal ball|dmg|crystal balls} to stay abreast of events happening in the wider world. She has agents in Waterdeep and Neverwinter who she wishes to protect, and the great fleets of pirates amassing in the south and beginning to worry her. She knows that would-be adventurers have their work cut out for them, and wishes to offer assistance. As the characters travel through her forest, Old Gnawbone's woodland spies (birds, rodents, and other harmless forest critters) warn her of their presence. She decides to leave her lair to confront them. The characters hear something enormous approaching through the dark woods and tangled underbrush, and might be startled when a green dragon's head bursts into view with the tenderised corpse of an Uthgardt barbarian dangling from its mouth.

If the characters attack Claugiyliamatar, she breathes poison gas at them, takes to the air, and returns to her hidden lair. She has little interest in killing for the sake of it, and has already got a substantial meal. If the characters act peacefully and talk to her, she tells them (in {@language Common}) to travel south to the Nelanther Isles and search for a ship graveyard called Driftwood Docks. "Therein," she says, "you'll learn what must be done to end the pirate menace." Once she has imparted this information, Old Gnawbone takes flight and returns to her lair to finish off her meal.

{@creature Claugiyliamatar|skt} is an {@creature ancient green dragon}, with the following {@footnote additional features|Included in the linked statblock.} that increase her challenge rating to 23 (50,000 XP).

items.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Claugiyliamatar's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 19). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

items: 1/day each: {@spell invisibility}, {@spell legend lore}, {@spell protection from energy}, {@spell true seeing}

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: Claugiyliamatar is an 8th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 18, +10 to hit with spell attacks). She has the following druid spells prepared:

items: Cantrips (at will): {@spell druidcraft}, {@spell mending}, {@spell produce flame}
1st level (4 slots): {@spell cure wounds}, {@spell detect magic}, {@spell entangle}, {@spell speak with animals}
2nd level (3 slots): {@spell animal messenger}, {@spell pass without trace}
3rd level (3 slots): {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell plant growth}
4th level (2 slots): {@spell blight}, {@spell locate creature}, {@spell stoneskin}

entries.name: Lathtarl's Lantern
entries: Lathtarl's Lantern was a notorious wrecking site where pirates would light lanterns to lure merchant vessels into rocky reefs and scupper them. Nowadays, Lathtarl has cleaned up its act somewhat. Instead of luring merchants to their doom with ghostly lights, Lathtarl now lures them in with the opportunity for a hearty meal and cheap drink at the famous Wailing Wave inn.

Lathtarl's Lantern is a base for the Scaly Eye Merchant Company, run by Lhammaruntosz the ancient bronze dragon who lairs on Orlumbor. Mother Claws, as she is known, has many agents in Lantern who help keep her merchant ships safe and fend off pirates who give chase.

Lantern is 'ruled' by Irak Pholdaruk (NG male Chondathan human {@creature commoner}), a cheery old man with an enormous moustache whose ancestor forged the connection with Mother Claws. Pholdaruk has no official title, though the Lanternites often refer to him as Mayor.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters who visit Lathtarl's Lantern are urged to meet with Mayor Pholdaruk in the Wailing Wave, where he spends most of his evenings. Pholdaruk asks if the characters would pay Mother Claws a visit on the island of Orlumbor (see the "{@area Orlumbor|orlumbor|x}" section). He's heard that some of the Scaly Eye ships have gone missing in the south and is extremely worried about the pirate presence along the Sword Coast. In addition, something is seriously wrong with Roaringshore—a pirate hold only two days south of Lantern. Normally the place is dangerous enough, but hideous, crustacean-like creatures have been appearing from the town's direction and attacking Lantern. As if on cue, screams can be heard from outside the tavern as two {@creature uchuulon|CallfromtheDeep|uchuulons} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) attack the village. These are the experiments of G'zagrix, a mind flayer who makes its home in the Broken Goblet tavern of Roaringshore.

entries.name: Leilon
entries: Leilon is a small town near the High Road, straddling the distance between mines in the mountains and mudflats on the coast from which its people would send out barges of ore to waiting ships. For many years, the town stood abandoned because the protective magic around a wizard's tower, called the House of Thalivar, went awry causing any who looked at it to be paralyzed. The few travellers still taking the High Road and braving the expansion of the Mere of Dead Men had to travel for miles around Leilon or pass by at night to avoid the tower's mysterious power. When Lord Neverember decided to reopen the High Road, tearing down the tower became a top priority. It is now safe to pass through Leilon, and it is once again a working town, but all who live there owe allegiance to Lord Neverember.

Despite Neverember staking a claim to Leilon, the real governing force in the town are the Zhentarim. The town has become a base of operations through which pirate crews are hired, and the place is crawling with cutthroats and thugs. Overseeing the negotiations is 'Lady' Vonda Agosto (LE female Turami human {@creature assassin}), a high-ranking Zhentarim agent. Vonda is a breeder of flying snakes and is constantly surrounded by at least five of the reptiles (use the {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes} statistics with a fly speed on 60 ft.). Characters who wish to travel through Leilon must pay a gate toll of 1 sp to enter the town, collected by gangs of six Zhentarim {@creature thug|mm|thugs} that loiter around the ramshackle wall. There is no charge for characters who can prove their affiliation with the Black Network.

Leilon provides the perfect opportunity for characters to meet with pirates anonymously, as the inhabitants here are constantly swapping between towns and boats. Characters who spend time at The Orc's Tusks, the favoured tavern, can gather rumours of the Nelanthers, the Black Armada, Sea King Tentrix, and his floating lair in Driftwood Docks. The DM should choose exactly what information becomes available to the characters. The owner of the Tusks is an undercover Harper agent named Gorunn Bronzebelly (NG male shield dwarf {@creature spy}). If he spots other Harper agents in this tavern, he winks at them and subtly flashes his harper symbol in their direction. If they meet with him privately, he warns them not to stay in Leilon for too long. Gorunn warns the characters that the following afternoon there will be a raid by the Order of the Gauntlet, who have heard about the mercenary antics of the Zhentarim based here.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The afternoon following the characters arrival is interrupted by the sound of commotion at the walls of the town and the thundering of hooves. Storming into the settlement come six {@creature knight|mm|knights} on {@creature riding horse|mm|riding horses} led by Shandri Dundragon (LG female Chondathan human {@creature priest} of {@deity Helm|Faerûnian|SCAG}; see {@adventure chapter 1|CallfromtheDeep|2|Shandri Dundragon|0}) mounted on a dappled grey {@creature warhorse}. Shandri and the knights are members of the Order of the Gauntlet, who have discovered the Zhentarim operations in Leilon. The knights are searching for Vonda to imprison her at Helm's Hold for her criminal activity.

After only a few minutes a fight breaks out between the two factions. The Zhentarim attempt to rush Vonda out of the town on a {@creature riding horse} with an entourage of six {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}. Midda Goldbottle (NE female lightfoot halfling {@creature mage}) and four {@creature thug|mm|thugs} attempt to hold back the Order of the Gauntlet while Vonda flees.
If the party don't intervene, Vonda escapes while the knights are distracted. The Order take a casualty in the fighting and flee Leilon back to Helm's Hold.
If Shandri died earlier in the campaign, replace her with Harret Dundragon, her sister.

entries.name: Lizard Marsh
entries: Instead of flowing freely into the sea, the Delimbiyr River dissolves into a morass of waterways threading around and beneath trees festooned with moss, forming a vast swamp. Lizard Marsh is known for two things: bloodthirsty insects and dangerous monsters. In the event the characters find themselves here, use the {@filter Swamp Monsters|bestiary|environment=swamp} table in {@book appendix B|dmg|11} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to inspire encounter ideas.

Near the north-eastern edge of the Lizard Marsh stands Cromm's Hold, a squat stone keep surrounded by a wall. Baroness Wynne Cromm (LE female Illuskan human {@creature noble}) and her garrison of eighteen soldiers (male and female human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) watch the Lizard Marsh for signs of lizardfolk aggression.

entries.name: Longsaddle
entries: This sleepy frontier village, and member of the Lords' Alliance, straddles the Long Road, with rows of homes and businesses on either side of the trade route. Noteworthy establishments include a rustic inn called the Gilded Horseshoe and a friendly festhall called the Gambling Golem where card games, and a local marbles game called scattershields, are popular. Off in the distance, one can see horses and herds of cattle on sprawling ranches.

Monsters or brigands sometimes mistake Longsaddle for easy pickings—unaware that a family of powerful human wizards, the Harpells, lives nearby. Their grand house, Ivy Mansion, lies west of Longsaddle at the end of a long, winding path. The Harpells founded the village but take no part in its government, preferring to live quietly on their estate. Magical wards placed throughout Longsaddle and the Ivy Mansion warn the Harpells when trouble is afoot so they may come to the village's rescue.

entries.name: Lost Peaks
entries: These forested mountains rise from the northwest of the High Forest. Many fey dwell around the peaks, as does a tribe of centaurs who keep a careful eye on human hunters and woodcutters operating out of Olostin's Hold.

entries.name: Lurkwood
entries: The southern verge of the Lurkwood is safe enough to attract woodcutters, trappers, and hunters from Mirabar, Xantharl's Keep, and Longsaddle, but there's really no corner safe from the Uthgardt tribes that hunt here (primarily Black Raven and Thunderbeast barbarians).

entries.name: Luskan
entries: The City of Sails often conjures romantic images of a magnificent port metropolis, majestic merchant galleons with bright sails, and dashing swashbucklers who greet their enemies with a playful wink and a tip of the hat.

In reality, Luskan is anything but that. It's a dirty dive with filthy streets, squat buildings, ramshackle docks, creaky old longships, and crass pirates thinly disguised as sea traders. Rising above the fog and the stench is the Hosttower of the Arcane, home of a league of power-hungry wizards called the Arcane Brotherhood. Their ghastly tower branches into multiple thinner spires at the top. From a distance, the Hosttower might be mistaken for a giant, leafless tree. To those who have the misfortune of seeing it up close, it looks like a clawed hand bursting out of the ground, each of its fingers a tower with many peering windows.

Five High Captains rule the city. Each is a glorified pirate lord who controls a fleet of longships. The fleets serve many purposes: they defend Luskan against seafaring barbarians and other enemies, they conduct legitimate sea trade up and down the Sword Coast, and they raid and plunder the Island Kingdoms to the west (and the occasional settlement on the Sword Coast). The High Captains have no influence over the Arcane Brotherhood, nor is it apparent that the wizards have any allegiance to Luskan.

Luskan's best-kept secret is that the High Captains are under the sway of Jarlaxle Baenre, the leader of a clandestine brotherhood of drow mercenaries and rogues called Bregan D'aerthe. Jarlaxle is a master schemer (and master of disguise) who would like to bring Luskan into the Lords' Alliance. Unfortunately the City of Sails has such an unsavoury reputation, and so little to offer, that most alliance members won't allow it. That doesn't stop Jarlaxle from trying, especially now that the Alliance has lost two members: Everlund and Sundabar.

Druette the Raven of the Arcane Brotherhood is also a member of the Kraken Society. Slarkrethel contacted her before Zellix'Phor overcame him, but the connection has been maintained by the elder brain to great effect. Druette is currently of convincing Third High Captain Dagmaer Suljack (of Ship Suljack) to allow more pirate crews into Luskan for safe haven, despite protestations from the Lords' Alliance. There are often several such vessels taking refuge in Luskan's Harbour where they cannot be touched by Gundarlun's kingsfleet or the Neverwinter navy.
For more information about Luskan, see the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag|2|Luskan}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The first time characters spend time in Luskan, they are approached by {@creature Jarlaxle Baenre|wdh} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) disguised as a sun elf ship captain called Jalinndan Baelkiir. He politely enquires about their business in Luskan and eventually asks them to meet with him the following day in a tavern named One-Eyed Jax, if they are looking for more work.

If characters meet with Jarlaxle, he informs them that Luskan has been showing increased leniency toward pirates lately, providing shelter for crews actively being chased by the Lords' Alliance. He needs someone to investigate the Arcane Brotherhood for him as he is positive that one of the members is working with the pirates. Characters can track down members of the Brotherhood by asking around Luskan, using downtime to {@variantrule Downtime Activity: Research|xge|research} their location, or using spells to ascertain their whereabouts. The members of the Brotherhood and their locations are:

items.name: Cashaan the Red, Archamge of the Arcane
items.entry: (N male Calishite human {@creature necromancer|vgm}): Hosttower of the Arcane. Cashaan is the newly appointed archmagi, who earned the title by ousting the undead that previously occupied the Hosttower. If questioned, Cashaan laughs in the faces of the party, claiming he couldn't care less about the goings on of Luskan.

items.name: Zelenn the White, Overwizard of the West
items.entry: (LN female moon elf {@creature evoker|vgm}): Neverwinter. Zelenn is from Neverwinter and has strong ties to Lord Neverember. If the party call her into question, she produces papers linking her with Neverember and, by association, the Lords' Alliance.

items.name: Jendrick the Blue, Overwizard of the South
items.entry: (CN male Illuskan human {@creature mage} with a {@item staff of frost}): Dougan's Hole. Jendrick is currently lying low after a failed takeover of Icewind Dale which would have made him Archmage. Jendrick has strong associations with pirates, including the crew of the Howling Fiend (see the "{@area Icewind Dale|icewind dale|x}" section). He's perfectly happy with the Ships of Luskan allowing more piracy, but it wasn't his doing. He suspects Druette the Raven, who's been acting strangely recently; talking to herself, drawing strange symbols on the walls, and staring out to sea for hours on end.

items.name: Teyva the Gray, Overwizard of the East
items.entry: (NE female half-elf {@creature illusionist|vgm}): Baldur's Gate. Teyva is a self-taught mage and expert thief whose skills lie in diplomacy rather than arcane talent. She's currently trying to gain influence in Baldur's Gate but to little effect. She knows little of what's occurring in Luskan, as she's focussed on the south.

items.name: Druette the Raven, Overwizard of the North
items.entry: (N female Illuskan human {@creature diviner|vgm} with a {@item cloak of the bat}): Port Llast. Druette is a member of the Kraken Society who is being influenced by the elder brain Zellix'Phor. She has convinced Third High Captain Dagmaer Suljack (of Ship Suljack), to allow more pirate crews into Luskan for safe haven. She isn't aware that she works for the Kraken but knows of other Kraken Society members, such as Dread High Trident Abeline Nerovarco. Druette only reveals this information if her life is at risk. If she starts spouting names or locations associated with the Kraken Society, Zellix'Phor deals 70 psychic damage to her, enough to kill Druette instantly. Characters might uncover that Druette is responsible by spying on her or talking with her fellow Brotherhood members.

entries: Jarlaxle (in disguise) asks that the characters seek him out once they've identified who is responsible for the pirate sheltering. They can find him here at the tavern or on his ship, The Eyecatcher, in Luskan's harbour. If the characters report back to Jarlaxle, he arranges for the drow of Bregan D'aerthe, his mercenary company, to assassinate Druette.

If any of the characters are drow, or if they volunteer to help kill Druette, Jarlaxle is inclined to reveal his true identity to them. If they agree to join Bregan D'aerthe, he gives them control over his submarine, the {@item Scarlet Marpenoth|CallfromtheDeep} (AC 20, 300 hit points, damage threshold 15, speed 2 mph, 5 crew, 10 passengers, 2 tons of cargo) and its five {@creature drow elite warrior} crew.

entries.name: Maelstrom
entries: Maelstrom lies on the floor of the Trackless Sea, nearly 3,000 feet beneath the surface. For centuries it has been the stronghold of the world's most powerful storm giant royals. The undersea fortress of King Hekaton is carved into a reef which boasts four rocky towers covered in barnacles and corals that reach skyward. Between the towers is a large sinkhole that descends into the heart of the fortress. A natural phenomenon sometimes causes the ocean currents at the surface to form a great whirlpool with enough strength to draw ships down into it. These vessels are torn apart as they are pulled down, and the wreckage is deposited at the bottom of the sinkhole, where {@creature hulking crab|skt|hulking crabs} pick through it for their storm giant masters.

The easiest and safest way to reach Maelstrom is with teleportation magic. Characters can also reach Maelstrom by ship through the sinkhole. Any ship that sails over Maelstrom encounters a giant whirlpool, which inexorably draws the vessel into the depths.

entries.name: Skill Challenge
entries: The characters must succeed on five DC 20 ability checks before failing three to avoid being drawn into the whirlpool. Allow any reasonable skill to be used, such as the following examples:

items: Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to row the ship away
Dexterity check to furl the sails and avoid the wind
Constitution check to keep your stomach on the swirling ship
Intelligence check to calculate an angle of escape
Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to observe the rips of the current
Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check to inspire the crew

entries: If the characters fail three checks before succeeding on five, the ship's hull is torn apart and its wreckage sucked to the bottom of a sinkhole in the heart of the stronghold. Creatures aboard the vessel must make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. There's no air in the sinkhole, so characters who survive the shipwreck must hold their breath, locate an air pocket, or use magic to breathe. Characters who are drawn down into the depths must also contend with water pressure (see "{@hazard Water Pressure|CallfromtheDeep}" sidebar).
If the characters succeed on five checks before failing three, they manage to navigate their ship around the whirlpool and avoid Maelstrom altogether.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: A full map of the locations in Maelstrom can be found in {@adventure chapter 10|skt|11|Maelstrom} of {@i Storm King's Thunder}.

The first time the characters enter Maelstrom they are apprehended by two {@creature storm giant|mm|storm giants} who grab them in their enormous hands and carry them to Imperator Uthor, a weather-beaten giant with a long, braided beard. Rather than being angry with them for invading the fortress, Uthor is eager to hear what the 'small-folk' have to say about the surface. Uthor rarely leaves the depths of the ocean, but if the crushed vessels which are pulled down into Maelstrom are anything to go by, all is not well.

If the characters mention increased piracy, Uthor seems unsurprised and explains that many of the ships caught in the whirlpool above Maelstrom have been flying black banners. Sometimes the vessels are filled with human captives, other times with strange items that wouldn't normally be taken by pirates, such as books, art, and tools.

If the characters mention the Kraken Society, Uthor's face grows grave. He sends the guards to bring King Hekaton to a scrying pool and heads there with the characters. When Hekaton arrives, Uthor introduces the characters to the giant king and explains the actions of the Kraken Society to him. Hekaton reveals that the Kraken Society is more than a faction of telepathically linked agents; it is genuinely controlled by an ancient and evil kraken named Slarkrethel. The kraken has bothered Hekaton many times before, but he has never taken such an interest in the mainland before. Hekaton uses the pool to cast {@spell scrying} on Slarkrethel. As he does so, each creature in the room has their head filled with visions of writhing, slimy tentacles which cause their heads to throb. They are then bombarded with images in quick succession: babies being thrown from cliffs into the ocean, human limbs warping into piscine appendages, brains mutating and blackening, and hideous, tentacled creatures emerging from the depths of the ocean onto the shore.

Hekaton immediately knows something is amiss. Slarkrethel is normally arrogant enough to allow himself to be seen. He tells the characters that their best bet at uncovering what is causing this is Purple Rocks. The people there venerate Slarkrethel and are likely to know more. Hekaton sends a {@creature storm giant} named Ygdis with the characters and gives them a {@item conch of teleportation|skt} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) which returns them to Maelstrom if blown.

entries.name: Mere of Dead Men
entries: The kingdom that stood here long ago was washed away when a lich named Iniarv caused the sea to flow inland. The swamp gets its name from the thousands who died in the flood. Travellers on the High Road, which skirts the Mere to the east, must resist the urge to be lured into the swamp by bobbing {@creature will-o'-wisp|mm|will-o'-wisps}. Countless adventurers have perished in here, drawn by tales of ruined castles half-sunk in the mire. These once noble estates are now home to lizardfolk, undead, and worse. The greatest threats to treasure hunters are the {@creature ancient black dragon} twins Voaraghamanthar and Waervaerendor. While the former is considered the undisputed Lord of the Mere the latter is hardly known at all and the two dragons like it that way.
If the characters explore the Mere, use the {@filter Swamp Monsters|bestiary|environment=swamp} table in appendix B of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to inspire encounter ideas.

entries.name: Mintarn
entries: Mintarn has long been a neutral ground for various forces, a place aloof from the conflicts of coastal city-states and the rivalries of the Northlander isles. Any ship, be it pirate, privateer, or merchant vessel, could dock at Mintarn and find a warm welcome. Many treaties were struck on its shores, and when peace couldn't be achieved, soldiers and ships from Mintarn hired themselves out to various power groups, with no fear of retribution on their home.

Not long ago Mintarn was awash with coin thanks to Dagult Neverember's White Sails ship-building company, and his coin funnelled through Waterdeep after their navy was wasted chasing pirates. On top of this, Neverember began hiring Tarnian mercenaries to fill the ranks of the Neverwinter Watch.

Unfortunately, the weight of gold on the island awoke Hoondarrh—the Red Rage of Mintarn, an ancient red dragon to whom the northlanders paid yearly tribute. Hoondarrh wanted to increase the annual tithe and laid waste to Castle Mintarn to make his point. The folk of Mintarn scrambled to meet the impatient wyrm's demands and could do little to resist him as their soldiers served in foreign armies. Since that fateful day, and Neverember's exile from Waterdeep, things haven't been great for Mintarn. The place still has plenty of cosy inns and an abundance of brilliant green wine but the locals are starting to get desperate.

The current Tyrant of Mintarn is Bloeth Embuirhan (LN female Chondathan human {@creature gladiator} with 90 hit points) who's trying against the odds to keep Hoondarrh satisfied. The dragon lives on a mountain named Skadaurak that rises from the ocean to the north of Mintarn. His tributes are left on a sandy beach inside a sea cave. Many more caverns spread out from the tithe cave, and the Red Rage's snoring echoes throughout.
The characters might end up on Mintarn if they accept Len-jes' Quest in {@area chapter 2|nwqlq|x}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters may try and plunder the great hoard of Hoondarrh while they visit Mintarn. Rumours abound about the treasures that lie within his cavernous lair on Skadaurak, including a magic pearl which prevents aging, a dozen human skulls of solid ruby, and a life-sized dragon made entirely of gold. The locals also claim that the Red Rage slumbers for most of the year. He only awakes when it comes time to receive tribute from the Tarnians.

Characters who venture to Skadaurak discover that the island is a hollowed-out mountain with several sea caves permitting entrance at ocean level. There is no sign of the dragon, nor of his hoard, from the outside. Characters who enter the sea caves hear the slow rise and fall of Hoondarrh's snores, a steady beat which gives the characters warning of the dragon's waking. Hoondarrh has riddled his lair with a variety of traps, both simple and complex, always deadly. Use the {@filter examples|trapshazards|type=!ENV;!GEN;!HAZ;!WTH;!WLD} in chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} and chapter 2 of {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything} to inspire the lair's defences. When the characters start exploring, and each time they trigger a trap, have them make a DC 26 group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to avoid waking Hoondarrh. If the characters fail three such checks, the Red Rage stops snoring and begins to awaken.

The characters have {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds to escape before Hoondarrh wakes and searches them out. If the characters pass five traps without waking the dragon, they can plunder his hoard. Roll on the {@table Treasure Hoard: Challenge 17+} table in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what they find.

Hoondarrh is a truly ancient dragon obsessed with extending his life, which is the reason for his long slumbers. He delights in luring adventurers to his lair and seeing them dismembered by vicious traps. He guards his hoard and lair with his life, as losing control over Mintarn would deprive him of all his wealth. {@creature Hoondarrh|CallfromtheDeep} is an {@creature ancient red dragon} with the following {@footnote additional features|Included in the linked statblock.} that increase his challenge rating to 25 (75,000 XP).

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Hoondarrh has a magical emerald called Ongild (which functions as a {@item ring of regeneration} and gives him the Innate Spellcasting feature) embedded in his scaly hide, he carries a {@item rod of lordly might}, and wears a {@item ring of feather falling}.

items.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Hoondarrh's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 22; {@hit +10} to hit with spell attacks). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

items: 1/day each: {@spell delayed blast fireball}, {@spell prismatic spray}, {@spell reverse gravity}

items.name: Spellcasting
entries: Hoondarrh is a 14th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save DC 20; {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). He has the following wizard spells prepared:

items: Cantrip (at will): {@spell blade ward}, {@spell mending}, {@spell message}, {@spell ray of frost}
1st level (4 slots): {@spell alarm}, {@spell mage armor|phb|mage armour}, {@spell magic missile}, {@spell shield}
2nd level (3 slots): {@spell arcane lock}, {@spell darkness}, {@spell detect thoughts}
3rd level (3 slots): {@spell counterspell}, {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell haste}
4th level (3 slots): {@spell banishment}, {@spell greater invisibility}, {@spell stoneskin}
5th level (2 slots): {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell wall of force}
6th level (1 slot): {@spell flesh to stone}, {@spell globe of invulnerability}
7th level (1 slot): {@spell symbol}, {@spell teleport}

entries.name: Mirabar
entries: Mirabar is the richest city of the North by far. It sits atop a knoll on the north side of the Mirar River like an unassailable fortress, enclosed on all sides by sloped outer walls as wide at the base as many city blocks in Waterdeep. Defenders can fire arrows down from atop the walls or, in winter, pour water down them to make ice slides. There is no shortage of stone and weaponry. Even the docks have battlements and fortifications.

Visitors to Mirabar often wonder why they don't see more dwarves, as humans make up the majority of the city's surface dwellers. Another city lies just below the surface and that place is dominated by dwarves. Underground, Mirabar is a city of lit residential caverns, superheated forges, foundries that operate day and night, and tunnels leading to the mines.

They city's marchion, Selin Ramur (LN male Damaran human {@creature noble}), meets with the other members of the Lords' Alliance to ensure Mirabar's interests aren't ignored by other members. While the marchion handles foreign policy, true power within the city rests with the Council of Sparkling Stones. This group of shield dwarf elders manages security in Mirabar and decides where the output of the city's mines are sold. The city's defence falls to the Axe of Mirabar, an elite, well-armed shield dwarf garrison. A {@creature axe of mirabar soldier|skt|typical member} is a {@creature veteran}, with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: A member of the Axe of Mirabar has AC 18 ({@item plate armor|phb|plate}), 67 ({@dice 9d8 + 27}) hit points, and a speed of 25 feet.
They have a Constitution score of 16 ({@d20 3}) and {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.
They speak {@language Common} and {@language Dwarvish}.
They have advantage on saving throws against poison and resistance to poison damage.
They wield a {@item battleaxe|phb} instead of a {@item longsword|phb} and a {@item handaxe|phb} instead of a {@item shortsword|phb}.

entries: The rugged land around Mirabar is littered with mine heads, open quarries, and heaps of slag and rubble. The mines of Mirabar yield vast quantities of most known metals and gemstones. Working mines of any significance are heavily fortified. All miners who enter, dwarf and human, are searched before and after shifts ensuring security. It is an inconvenience the miners accept because, unlike many other places in the North, Mirabar pays well and cares for the workers.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The fortified docks of Mirabar berth a ship called The Carny. It is almost as broad as it is long and has a huge, striped big top tethered to its deck. A wooden sign by the ship reads: "The greatest floating show you'll ever see! Fireflinging, sword-swallowing, tiger-taming and more! Shows at high noon and dusk. 5 sp a ticket, 1 sp for children."

Standing next to the sign is a bedraggled girl wearing a brightly coloured tunic and jester hat. Characters who succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notice a sulphurous smell about her. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, they notice a strand of red slime trailing from her ankle to the ship. The girl, who introduces herself as 'Little Lion', is a simulacrum formed by an {@creature elder oblex|mtf} which lairs in the hold of The Carny. The ooze was created by Zellix'Phor and the illithid colony and is being used to spy on Mirabar and capture choice victims for the mind flayers. Any creature memory drained by the oblex has its memories telepathically transmitted to Zellix'Phor.

The shows on The Carny are enormously entertaining. They deliver all the sign promises and more, wrapped up in the spectacular showmanship of Belladonna Beguile, a charming ringmistress who wears a purple top hat and tails. Before the show commences, Belladonna announces the presence of Gilthur Goldfinder (LN male shield dwarf {@creature noble}), an esteemed member of the Council of Sparkling Stones. Gilthur stands to face the audience, bowing deeply.
Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the following strange occurrences throughout the show:

items: The fire is fake—a {@spell minor illusion} effect.
One of the sword-swallowers seems to cut the side of his mouth but no blood spouts from the wound.
One of the two {@creature tiger|mm|tigers} in the show swipes at the tamers, seemingly catching one of them with its claws, though neither tamer reacts.
The whole place has a vague scent of rotten eggs.

entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score 23 or higher notice slime strands trailing from each performer. The oblex has an array of thirteen performers (including Belladonna and Little Lion) in its retinue of simulacra but also has ten {@creature guard|mm|guards} thralls to keep order.

At some point during the show, the oblex takes the Eat Memories action through Belladonna on Gilthur. It appears as if the dwarf has a stroke and he is quickly removed from the ship by two of the guards. The following day, The Carny leaves Mirabar down the River Mirar toward the coast.

entries.name: Misty Forest
entries: This evergreen forest gets its name from the fog that creeps down from the High Moor and enshrouds it, making navigation difficult on even the best of days. The forest is patrolled by wood elves, who defend the woods from poachers. Visitors who leave the inhabitants of the Misty Forest alone, and who build their campfires small and solely of fallen branches, are usually not disturbed.

entries.name: Mithral Hall
entries: The ancestral home of the Battlehammer clan of shield dwarves is a nigh-impregnable vault beneath the Frost Hills, with massive granite doors sealing its entrance and a host of battle-hardened defenders waiting beyond. Despite its almost mythic reputation, Mithral Hall is more of a stronghold than city, with tunnels to other dwarfholds hidden deep below its mines.

Bruenor Battlehammer gave up the title of King of Mithral Hall for the third and final time when he set out to reclaim the city of Gauntlgrym. His handpicked successor, Dagnabbet Waybeard, now rules Mithral Hall as queen. A bold leader and a fierce warrior, Queen Dagnabbet firmly supports Mithral Hall's membership in the Lords' Alliance.

entries.name: Moray
entries: To the west of Gwynneth, Moray is a land at war with itself. The embattled Ffolk of Caer Moray struggle to keep the port town open so that Dynnegall, farther inland, can receive vital supplies. These supplies include reinforcements to deal with the threats of the island which are many and varied: the Black Blood tribe of Malarworshiping werefolk, the giants of the Trollclaw Range, and the ogres and orcs of the Orcskill Mountains. The Ffolk of Moray are loyal to the High King. They hope for a return to a unified Moonshaes under the Kendrick banner and are determined to hold on long enough to see it.

Caer Moray is little more than a walled port that is home to the majority of humans on the isle. Beyond its walls are numerous fishing and farming villages called cantrevs. Many of these are situated in the lush, fertile valley of the Shannyth River.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The characters are sought out by Ursa Thickhide (NG female Illuskan human {@creature werebear}), a member of the Emerald Enclave who has a quest for them. She and four others were sent to the island to help protect the Moonwells, pool of sacred water, from the Black Blood Tribe, who are sacrificing humanoids in these pools in an attempt to summon an aspect of {@deity Malar|Faerûnian|scag}. The group were tricked by a jackalwere and led into a dead-end pass where they were ambushed by a gang of lycanthropes. Usra managed to escape, but the others were killed, or so she thought. In the last few days Warpip, a squirrel belonging to Ellawick Gnackle, scampered from the woods to Ursa and brought news that Ellawick was imprisoned in a Black Blood encampment in the Trollclaw Range, a half day's walk from Caer Moray.

If characters agree to assist Ursa and the Emerald Enclave they can travel with the werebear to the Black Blood encampment, which is little more than a wooden hut and half a dozen tents surrounded by a hastily erected palisade wall. The camp contains four {@creature werewolf|mm|werewolves}, two {@creature jackalwere|mm|jackalweres} that guard the prisoners in the hut, and {@creature Rugrig Foamtankard|CallfromtheDeep}, a {@creature wereboar} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.} that increase his challenge rating to 5 (1,800 XP):

items: Rugrig wears {@item spiked armor|scag|spiked armour} (AC 14 in humanoid form).
Rugrig has 120 hit points.

Rugrig wields {@item clawed gauntlet|CallfromtheDeep|clawed gauntlets} instead of a {@item maul|phb}: {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage. If Rugrig attacks with the gauntlets, he can make an additional gauntlet attack as a bonus action. A character proficient with {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} is considered proficient with the gauntlets.
Rugrig wears a {@item periapt of wound closure}.

entries: The hut contains five prisoners; Ellawick Gnackle (CG female forest gnome {@creature druid}), Rhydian Morgan (LG male Ffolk human {@creature commoner}), and three {@creature orc|mm|orcs} named Urzul (male), Shamog (male), and Baggi (female). Each is locked in a wooden cage secured with a padlock. Rugrig has the keys to each cage. The locks can be picked with a successful DC 10 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or smashed apart (AC 15, 30 hit points). Any noise alerts the surrounding creatures. Any damage dealt beyond the cage's hit points is transferred to the prisoner within. The prisoners are kept suppressed by the Sleep Gaze of the jackalwere guards. If characters stake out the prison and succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check they overhear the jackalweres talking about sacrificing the prisoners tomorrow.

The following day the prisoners are loaded up on a cart, pulled by a captured {@creature aurochs|vgm} belonging to the orcs, and taken to a Moonwell three hours away. Unless the characters intervene they are sacrificed there one by one, turning the glistening water of the pond a deep red and allowing the Black Bloods to commune with {@deity Malar|Faerûnian|scag}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each werewolf member of the Black Blood Tribe carries {@dice 2d10} gp in a pouch. Rugrig wears an electrum {@item signet ring|phb} (worth 50 gp) bearing the bear paw symbol of {@deity Malar|Faerûnian|scag}.

entries.name: Murann
entries: Murann, the Sailor's City, is the second largest city in Amn. It lies at the western end of the Tethir Road in the Tarseth Bay. The city's economy is based entirely on ocean trade, and goods travel both ways between the city all the way to the continent of Maztica. The city is occupied mostly by merchants, shipwrights, and the Harbour Guard who defend the port against pirates and the Shadow Thieves guild operating out of Amn. The city is ruled by a parliament of merchant family heads, who try to ensure the port stays open at all times, and trade remains firmly in Muranni favour. The families in the parliament are the Hirehooks, the Nubaedfyd, the Kaptonnemes, the Luraxxol, the Ophals, and the Tuskar.

Thanks to the Harbour Guard, Murann is a relatively safe city to visit. The biggest dangers facing the populace are the ever-present Shadow Thieves who organise crime throughout Amn, and the tribes of ogres, led by powerful oni, who attack out of the Tejarn Hills to the east of the city.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: The first time characters enter the city, they find that the harbour is under attack by a sentient {@item galleon|CallfromtheDeep} called {@item Dreadcutter|CallfromtheDeep}. The galleon bristles with weaponry and flies a black pennant. Dreadcutter is a sentient chaotic evil ship with an Intelligence of 16, a Wisdom of 10, and a Charisma of 18. It has hearing out to a range of 120 feet. The ship can speak and read Common, and communicate telepathically with any creature within 120 feet of it in a malicious, snarky tone. Dreadcutter is arrogant and egotistic, desiring nothing more than to become the most feared pirate vessel on the Sword Coast. The ship was created when a drow wizard took her life aboard the galleon. Her soul lingers in the ship but retains no memory of her life.

Dreadcutter is a magical sentient construct. It has AC 15, 300 hit points, and a damage threshold of 20. It is equipped with two {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, a {@object mangonel}, and a {@object ram}, and can make one attack with each per turn. A character can attune to and interact with Dreadcutter as if it were a sentient weapon, though Dreadcutter attempts to take control of its wielder if it doesn't sink at least one ship per tenday.

Dreadcutter was hired by Sea King Tentrix to attack Murann as part of the Sword Coast offensive. A character who attunes to Dreadcutter can get this information from the ship so long as they comply with Dreadcutter's wishes. If the characters don't intervene, Dreadcutter destroys the majority of Murann's naval forces before taking off toward Asavir's Channel. As it leaves, the sound of harsh cackling sweeps in on the wind.

entries.name: Narino
entries: Narino is an abandoned merfolk city south of Mintarn. The merfolk there were once a society of wealthy merchants who traded pearls and corals to the Tarnians, as well as Waterdhavian and Neverwintian merchants. However, after Mintarn's fortunes turned the settlement went into decline. Without trade to support them, more and more merfolk left.

To make matters worse, a ship sailing atop Narino dropped a coffin of black mahogany overboard which landed in the underwater market. The coffin contained Mei Ling, a vampire who quickly adapted to her new underwater environment. She fed voraciously on the merfolk that remained and since turned the city into her lair.
Characters might end up Narino if they accept Len-jes' Quest in {@area chapter 2|nwqlq|x}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: While exploring the underwater city, the characters are certain to come across the largest building in the ruins; a palace carved from an enormous boulder covered with corals and anemones. The lower levels of the palace which served as living quarters and banquet halls have, for the most part, caved in, leaving only the upper levels open. It is here that the vampire Mei Ling resides.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Narino (Player).jpg}.}

At the top of a smooth, spiralling corridor is a domed chamber with a gallery above. The room is lit by magical light which causes the pearls set into the architraves to glisten. Dozens of tiny fish flitter in shoals around the chamber and crustaceans scuttle across the floor. The walls of the gallery above sport a leering gargoyle with twinkling sapphire eyes.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: As the characters explore the chamber, Mei Ling swims down from the gallery above. The vampire introduces herself to the characters and asks why they have visited her. She is a gracious host, though has a habit of invading people's personal space and never seems to blink. Mei Ling prefers not to create vampire spawn but might do so if one of the characters takes her fancy.
{@creature Mei Ling|CallfromtheDeep} uses the statistics of a {@creature vampire} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: She has AC 18 (natural armour, {@item bracers of defense})
She has a swim speed of 30 feet.
She transforms into a {@creature quipper} rather than a {@creature bat} using her Shapechange feature.
The natural currents of the ocean don't count as 'running water' for any of Mei Ling's features.
She wields a {@item vicious greatsword}: {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature, dealing 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage on a hit.

entries: If combat breaks out with Mei Ling in this chamber the four {@creature gargoyle|mm|gargoyles} (swim speed of 60 feet, fly speed 0 ft.) swoop down from the gallery above and assist their mistress.

entries.name: Light
entries: The room is continually lit with a permanent {@spell light} spell without a specific source.

entries.name: Gallery
entries: Overlooking the main chamber, at a height of 30 feet, is a gallery. Nothing prevents creatures swimming between the two levels. There are several windows, barred by coral growths, that look out over the ruined city.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters with an edged tool, such as a {@item dagger|phb}, can spend 10 minutes prising pearls out of the chamber walls. Roll a {@dice d20} for each 10-minute period, up to a maximum of {@dice 3d20}. The characters recover a number of 10 gp pearls equal to that result. The sapphire eyes (1,000 gp each) of the gargoyles can also be removed. Doing so requires a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using an edged tool. Failure cracks the sapphire, rendering it worthless.

entries.name: Secret Corridor
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice bubbles collecting around the architrave of one of the recessed arches. A successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check allows a character to open the secret door by pressing a sequence of pearls whose lustre is diminished. If the pearls have been removed, the door cannot be opened in this way.

The door is warded with a {@spell symbol} spell with the Hopelessness effect, which is triggered when a non-undead creature opens the door. The {@spell symbol} can be spotted with a successful DC 25 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. If the symbol is triggered it also sets off an {@spell alarm} spell in Mei Ling's mind. The secret door on the other end of the corridor can be opened from the inside without a check.

entries.name: N2. Crypts

entries: The corridor ahead has four doors leading south and three alcoves on the north wall. Each alcove contains a bas relief of a regal merfolk wearing a wealth of jewellery.
The following information pertains to the specific crypts working from left (west) to right (east). The stone doors are named, save for the westernmost, where the name has been scratched off.

entries.name: Mei Ling's Coffin
entries: The door to this crypt is barred from the inside with three steel bars. It can be forced open with a successful DC 30 Strength check. Inside, the walls are decorated with dozens of skulls. Taking up most of the floor is a black mahogany coffin that is warded against degradation by the ocean. This is Mei Ling's resting place. Any creature other than Mei Ling who touches the coffin causes the skulls to animate and attack (use the {@creature swarm of quippers} statistics). There is a secret door in the rear of the crypt that can be spotted with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Opening the door requires a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.

entries.name: Elethera Strongcurrent's Tomb
entries: The door opens into a small chamber containing dozens of weapons and shields, and a large stone sarcophagus sculpted with scenes of battle. The weapons in the chamber are made of coral and shell and are still sharp. They include four {@item spear|phb|spears}, six {@item club|phb|clubs}, and two {@item shield|phb|shields}. The sarcophagus can be opened with a successful DC 15 Strength check. Inside is the skeleton of a merfolk holding a {@footnote {@i shield of missile catching}|This item doesn't exist, but the {@item shield of missile attraction} is the closest match. Otherwise, there are the {@item gloves of missile snaring} which can be reflavoured into a shield at your discretion.} made of an enormous scallop shell and a {@item +1 guardian spear|CallfromtheDeep|+1 spear with the Guardian property} (see {@table Special Features; What Minor Property Does It Have|dmg|chapter 7} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Mialenna Frozendepth's Tomb
entries: Growing from the walls of this chamber are dozens of oysters in a thick matt of mossy seaweed. The stone sarcophagus is decorated with streams of mother of pearl in a swirling pattern reminiscent of a whirlpool. The sarcophagus is covered with barnacles and can be opened with a successful DC 15 Strength check. Inside is the skeleton of a merfolk holding an enormous pearl which functions as a {@item crystal ball of mind reading}.

entries.name: Uthemaris Swiftwave's Tomb
entries: Hundreds of symbols cover the walls of this chamber in interlocking circles and spirals. The stone sarcophagus has different metals inlaid into it in a coiling motif. The sarcophagus is protected with an {@spell arcane lock} spell but can be opened with a successful DC 25 Strength check. Opening the sarcophagus reveals a merfolk skeleton interred with a {@item staff of withering} and a {@item circlet of blasting}. Taking either of the items causes a {@creature wraith} (with a 60 ft. swim speed) to attack the thief.
A spiral ramp leads up the side of the boulder to an empty chamber. The walls of the room have thousands of nooks cut into them, each of which holds a thin sheet of grey stone.

entries.name: Tablets
entries: Each stone sheet is inscribed with {@language primordial|phb|Aquan} runes, based on Dwarvish script. They detail the history of Narino and its peoples including their trade, worship, government, wars, and treasures. The entire collection (1,450 tablets) would take multiple trips to salvage. Each tablet weighs 5 lbs. and is worth 25 gp.

Practising his aim on wooden statues and shell shields at the far end of this room is a pallid merfolk wielding a beautifully ornamented crossbow. Hanging from hooks behind him are four more crossbows, each magnificent in its unique fashion.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When characters first enter the room Berriamo Deepcurrent, a merfolk {@creature vampire spawn} wielding an eel-like {@item +1 light crossbow}, is practising his aim on the statues. Berriamo has no loyalty to Mei Ling, who created him in a moment of weakness. The two rarely talk but cohabit out of a sense of family. Berriamo defends Narino, but doesn't rusk his life to protect Mei Ling.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hanging from hooks are a number of crossbows; a {@item heavy crossbow|phb} inlaid with mother of pearl (150 gp), a {@item light crossbow|phb} made of green crystal (75 gp), a scrimshawed {@item hand crossbow|phb} made of whalebone (125 gp), and a {@item hand crossbow of warning} made of twisted coral.
This arched corridor is supported by giant, twisted shells that serve as columns. Weaving between these is an enormous eel, whose green skin crackles with sparks.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Guarding the corridor is Mei Ling's pet {@creature giant lightning eel|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The eel attacks anyone it doesn't recognise but flees if reduced to half its hit points or less.

entries.name: Nesmé
entries: Despite a heroic effort to save the town, Nesmé fell during the War of the Silver Marches to a horde of orcs aided by an ancient white dragon named Arauthator. It was then conquered by drow until they too were forced to abandon it. Today, Nesmé lies in ruins, and monsters from the Evermoors thwart efforts to rebuild it.

The town stood on the east side of the Surbrin River, enclosed within a circular wall festooned with ballistae and catapults, and connected by a fortified bridge to a formidable castle on the west side of the river. This western bastion enclosed the docks, paddocks, and stock pens, and gave the populace a place to fall back to in the event the town was breached. Although the militia put up a good fight against the orcs, the town couldn't withstand the dragon's attacks. The castle on the western shore has partially collapsed, the bridge has been destroyed, and the town's defences have been torn down. Within the town walls, now breached in several places, are piles of debris that were once shops, taverns, inns, and festhalls. Skulls, bones, rusted armour, and broken weapons are all that remain of those killed by orc axes and the dragon's icy breath.

entries.name: Neverwinter
entries: Neverwinter is a prominent city on the Sword Coast. See chapter 2 "{@adventure Neverwinter|CallfromtheDeep|5}" or the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag|2|Neverwinter|0} for more information on this location.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Unless it has already occurred, you can run the "{@adventure Attack on Neverwinter|CallfromtheDeep|5|Attack on Neverwinter}" encounter (see chapter 2) when the characters visit the city.

entries.name: Neverwinter Wood
entries: The forest east of Neverwinter has a magical quality about it, or at least an air of mystical secrecy. Neverwinter Wood holds countless ruins and more than a few crumbling castles. The always-warm Neverwinter River, which flows out of the wood, has its source deep beneath Mount Hotenow, an active volcano in the northern reaches of the forest. The volcano last erupted some fifty years ago. Lava pouring from the mountain burned a wide swath through Neverwinter Wood, destroying everything it touched. New trees have begun to grow where the ancient ones stood, though the effect of the catastrophe is still plain to see.

entries.name: Norland
entries: North of Moray lies Norland, the stronghold of the Northlanders of the Moonshae Isles. Much has happened among the Norls of late, weakening their grip on the Moonshaes, but High King Kendrick lacks the power to capitalise on it. In recent years a Northlander woman calling herself {@creature the Storm Maiden|CallfromtheDeep} arose as a battle leader among them, which was unusual as Northlanders don't allow women to raid or fish. Said to be blessed by both {@deity Valkur|Faerûnian|scag} and {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} at her birth, the Storm Maiden gathered great numbers of Norls to her banner and it seemed she might contest the king for control of Norland. However, a decade ago, she became consumed by the power of Umberlee and she drove her followers on a mad quest to control the Sea of Swords. When she was eventually defeated, she and her ship vanished into the waves. She is known to be unable to drown, and many folk fear her return.

Rault the Wise (N male Illuskan human {@creature berserker}), King of the Norls, lost his elderly son and grandson in battles against the Storm Maiden, leaving his succession in question. He has a granddaughter of great spirit and wisdom, but in the patriarchal Northlander society, and so soon after the disastrous rise to power of the Storm Maiden, it is unthinkable that rule should fall to her. Rault rules from his castle on the eastern edge of Rogarsheim, and many jarls throughout the island bend the knee to him.

If the characters visit Rault in Rogarsheim and talk to him about the pirate attacks, he tells them that Norland has indeed been attacked many times by crews. He fears the Storm Maiden will return with a crew and try to take his throne. Rault asks the characters to track down the Storm Maiden (who is currently a Pirate Lord of Sea King Tentrix) and kill her. He suggests the characters visit {@area Oman's Isle|omans isle|x}. Although the place is swarming with giants, there is a tomb there that belongs to Thelgaar Ironhand, a powerful jarl who united the Northlanders. The cairn is said to hold magic items that could help the characters, namely a magic greatsword and an unsinkable longship. If the characters bring Rault the greatsword, they can keep the longship and anything else they find. Rault does not know that the Storm Maiden is soon to pilfer the cairn for herself.

entries.name: Oman's Isle
entries: Oman's Isle is a blasted place controlled by fomorians that hurl boulders at ships that come too close. The island is home to the ruins of the Iron Keep, once home to the island's rulers. The current ruler is Hathfell the {@creature ettin} who lairs in the Iron Keep with twelve {@creature fomorian|mm|fomorians}. The creatures attack non-giants on sight and fight to the death. They aim to corrupt a Moonwell on Oman's Isle and use it to travel to other Moonwells in the Moonshaes. This quest is aided Crughth Blacktusks, an {@creature orc claw of luthic|vgm}.

entries.name: Suggested Encounter
entries: Characters might visit Oman's Isle in search of the Cairn of Thelgarr Ironhand. The cairn is hidden in a forest, but most Norls (including {@area Rault the Wise|norland|x}) know its exact location. Although the cairn has not been breached by the giants, it is guarded day and night by two {@creature fomorian|mm|fomorians}.

When characters first arrive at the cairn, the fomorians are locked in combat with three {@creature chuul|mm|chuuls} which have been sent as a distraction by the Kraken Society. The Kraken Society members, led by the notorious Storm Maiden of Moray, accessed the cairn via a subterranean stream and are hoping to plunder its treasures.

The entrance to the cairn is a descending stair in the centre of a ring of standing stones. The stair is blocked by a huge stone which looks as if it could be rolled aside. Moving the stone requires a successful DC 15 Strength check.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Ironhand Cairn (Player).png}.}

At the bottom of the rough stone stair is an unlit chamber. Twisting roots push through the cobbled walls and the packed mud ceiling. A single exit on the southern wall leads further into the tomb. Standing either side of the door are two stone statues of northlander warriors.

entries.name: Light
entries: All chambers in the cairn are unlit.

entries.name: Statues
entries: A closer look at the statues reveals they are both clutching a wooden token in their left hand with a tree engraved upon it. Casting {@spell detect magic} on the tokens shows an aura of abjuration magic.

entries.name: Exit
